HEADLINE: High Prices For Energy Hold Down Job Growth

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
Job growth was surprisingly meager last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, in a sign that business executives have become worried that the economic damage from high energy prices might be growing.
 Still, wages in October rose at their fastest clip in more than two years, leaving open the possibility that the hiring slowdown will turn out to be temporary.
Employers added only 56,000 jobs in October, well below the 150,000 or so that are needed to keep pace with population growth. The Labor Department also said that 36,000 fewer jobs were added in August and September than previously estimated.
 ''Job growth has kind of stalled out,'' said Bill Cheney, chief economist of John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. ''It's a puzzle,'' he added, noting that economic growth, retail sales and other indicators remained strong. 
 Hiring over the last three months has fallen to its lowest level since the summer of 2003, when the economy finally began to emerge from a hiring slump that had lasted three and a half years. Recent hurricanes have played a role, leaving many Gulf Coast residents out of work, but job creation was also weak across much of the country last month, Kathleen P. Utgoff, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, told Congress. 
 With interest rates rising, the hot housing market cooling and energy costs coming off a two-decade high, some executives and economists are concerned that consumer spending will slow in coming months. For now, though, most forecasters expect hiring to pick up before the end of the year.
 As poor as the October hiring number was, the government's monthly employment report offered a number of reasons for optimism.
 The jobless rate fell slightly, to 5 percent from 5.1 percent. It is calculated from a survey of households, which economists consider less reliable than the much larger survey of businesses that produces the job-growth numbers.
 But the household survey sometimes captures hiring by small companies before the business survey does and in recent months has offered a rosier picture of the economy. Last month, for instance, the number of workers holding part-time jobs because they could not find full-time work dropped to its lowest point since 2002.
 The business survey, meanwhile, showed that the average wage for rank-and-file workers rose 8 cents last month, to $16.27 an hour. That is equal to an annualized increase of more than 6 percent.
 ''There is an increased level of business caution,'' Drew T. Matus, a senior economist at Lehman Brothers, said. ''But these kind of wage gains don't make sense in light of the low level of hiring unless business just decided to pause for the month.''
 Still, wage growth has risen less than 3 percent in the last year, while inflation has been running close to 4 percent, effectively cutting many workers' pay.
 The spike in inflation, caused largely by oil prices, seems to have soured many Americans on the economy, despite its continued growth. In a recent poll by the University of Michigan, 60 percent of people said that they expected the next five years to bring periods of widespread unemployment. 
 Not since 1992 have so many people given that answer. In the middle of last year, fewer than 40 percent of respondents did. 
 In October, car dealers, hotels, restaurants and movie and music studios all cut jobs. Department stores added fewer jobs than they typically do during October; that shows up as a loss in the Labor Department report, because the government adjusts its numbers to account for normal seasonal variations.
 Across the economy, in fact, employment rose by 702,000 jobs last month. But the government reported a seasonally adjusted gain of only 56,000 because most of the new jobs were part of the usual October jump in employment.
 John E. Silvia, chief economist of Wachovia Corporation, said many of the sectors cutting jobs depended on consumers, who might eventually react to high gasoline and heating prices by cutting other spending, even if they have yet to do so. On Thursday, retailers reported surprisingly good sales numbers for October. 
 ''It's hard to put this all together,'' said Mr. Cheney of John Hancock.
 Job gains last month came from manufacturers, banks, hospitals, doctors' offices, residential contractors and computer systems companies. The end of a strike by Boeing workers helped cause a jump in the number of workers at transportation-equipment factories, and the early rebuilding of the Gulf Coast probably pushed up construction employment.
 Economists still expect the Federal Reserve to keep raising its benchmark short-term interest rate in coming months in an effort to tame inflation. Alan Greenspan, the departing Fed chairman, testified to Congress Thursday that he viewed inflation as a bigger threat than weak economic growth.
 The Fed has increased the benchmark rate, now at 4 percent, during each of its last 12 policy-setting meetings. It seems poised to do so again at the two remaining meetings before Mr. Greenspan's retirement early next year; Ben S. Bernanke has been nominated as his successor. 
 Investors are predicting that the Fed will increase the rate at one of the first two meetings after Mr. Greenspan's departure but not at both, based on the price of a futures contract tied to Fed policy. 
 The widening of income inequality in recent years appeared to continue last month. Workers at financial, information and professional-services companies -- who tend to be highly paid -- all got big raises. Raises at factories, warehouses, tourism companies, schools and health care providers were smaller. 
 In his testimony this week, Mr. Greenspan said the country was going through ''a very marked changed in the distribution of income.''
 He added: ''We have clearly observed a major increase in the need for skilled workers to basically staff our ever increasingly complex technological capital stock.''
 The dropout rate in high schools and colleges was too high for the economy to be fully staffed with qualified workers, Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: Home Building Loses Its Commanding Lead in Setting Economy's Pace 

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE building of houses, which buoyed the American economy during the 2001 recession and then spurred the recovery, is no longer leading the economy up.
 Figures released this week by the Commerce Department showed that private construction spending set a record in September, but the third-quarter average was only 6.5 percent above the figure in the quarter a year ago, before adjusting for inflation. That matched the growth of the overall economy. By contrast, in 2004 residential construction spending was growing twice as fast as the overall economy. 
While home builders were raking in the money, other areas of construction were not nearly as strong. The most drastic change was in office construction, which set a record in December 2000, when spending hit a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $58 billion. By early 2003, the rate had fallen more than half, and most of that lost ground has not been made up.
 A result has been a fundamental shift in the proportion of private construction spending going to building homes and apartments. The proportion fluctuated around 60 percent of total spending for years, but now it is around 70 percent. That makes the economy potentially more vulnerable than it usually is if housing construction were to decline sharply.
 By contrast, office buildings now account for a little more than 4 percent of the private construction budget, half what they accounted for in 2000. Commercial building, of stores and malls, has not suffered as much, but it has lost a quarter of its market share.
 A person looking for signs of an American industrial revival -- or at least an end to decay -- could take heart from the figures for manufacturing construction. Its share of the total construction pie, above 9 percent a decade ago, fell to 3 percent but has now stabilized and even begun to edge up. In dollars, September spending was at an annual rate of $27.6 billion, up almost 40 percent from the low reached in February 2003.
 An area with little sign of a turnaround is utility construction. Spending on communications sites has stabilized, but power plant spending in September reflected an annual rate of $22.6 billion, the slowest pace since early 2001. Over all, the utility share of private construction spending is down to 4.2 percent, the lowest since the government began collecting such figures in 1993.
 There has been widespread talk of a cooling in the housing market, and mortgage applications have slowed in recent weeks -- possibly an indicator of slower sales to come. But while spending on residential construction is no longer rising at 20 percent or more a year, as it was a year ago, it is still rising. Builders, it appears, are not worried.

HEADLINE: Stirred, Not Shaken

BYLINE: By Liam M. Brockey. 
Liam M. Brockey teaches European history at Princeton.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J. 

 BODY:
ON Nov. 1, 1755, a powerful earthquake followed by a tidal wave laid low Lisbon, trapping thousands beneath rubble and ruins. To make matters worse, the hundreds of candles that had been lighted in honor of All Saints' Day at the city's churches toppled over, starting a fire that lasted for days. This succession of calamities occurred with such rapidity and force that Lisbon, as it had been known to plebeians and philosophes, was no more. 
 In Voltaire's ''Candide,'' the most famous account of the events of that day, the sight of such destruction spurred one of Candide's companions to take off on a looting spree but led another to wonder why such a dreadful event had occurred. ''It is surely the day of judgment,'' answered Voltaire's naif a moment before a chunk of flying masonry left him prostrate. 
But Candide soon found out that it was not the end of times and that the only judgment at hand was his own. After being denounced by a familiar of the Inquisition for listening with an air of approval to a heretical proposal, Candide was sent to be flogged at an auto-da-fe held amid the smoldering remains of the Portuguese capital -- a ceremony that was supposed to prevent future earthquakes.
 Candide escaped Lisbon and fled across miles of Iberian countryside for Cadiz, pulling the attentions of 18th-century European readers with him. Many no doubt agreed with Voltaire's judgment that Lisbon was a redoubt of superstition, a bastion of irrationality best wiped from the face of the earth. As far as they were concerned, Voltaire's subtitle, ''Optimism,'' was ill applied to the fortunes of the Portuguese capital. 
 But in little over a decade Lisbon rose spectacularly. Much of the dynamism behind its reconstruction was generated by one man, Sebastiao Jose de Carvalho, the Marquis of Pombal. During the 27-year reign of the distracted dilletante King Jose I, Pombal was chief minister and de facto head of state. It had taken the marquis 50 years to reach the summit of power, and the rebuilding of Lisbon was one of his greatest challenges. After all, the city's destruction required the wholesale re-creation of Portugal's financial and administrative systems. It demanded a leader with tremendous foresight and the political will to match -- not to mention the coercive force to transform his plans into reality. The discarded hulks of the Portuguese Inquisition and the Jesuit order were monuments to the strength of Pombal's will. 
 The marquis had an ambitious reconstruction plan. His goal was to transform Lisbon from a medieval jumble of irregular streets and awkward squares into a model of rational urban planning. Pombal commissioned a team of military engineers, led by an 80-year-old general, Manuel da Maia, to survey the city and oversee its reconstruction. 
 The new Lisbon would be a monument to the Enlightenment, a living metaphor of effective government. The rhythm of the city's heart would no longer be maintained by church bells and religious processions, but by the affairs of state. No church was built to command the city's new focal point. Instead, Pombal organized the government's ministries around a square that he dedicated to business, the Praca do Comercio. Even the names of the city's new arteries reflected Pombal's conviction that Lisbon needed earthly efforts rather than divine assistance to regain its prosperity; the Street of the Crucifix ceded its place of honor to the Street of Gold. 
 Other avenues saw age-old saintly patrons dismissed in favor of humble tradesmen like leatherworkers and shoemakers. And to ensure that future generations would not have to worry as much about future earthquakes, Pombal insisted on the use of wooden trusses and supports in every new edifice in Lisbon. These gaiolas, or cages, have been on duty for more than two centuries, absorbing the shocks of the odd tremor and ensuring that the legacy of the marquis stands firm.
 This week, even as Americans ponder how to raise one of their own great cities from the aftermath of disaster, Lisbon's grateful inhabitants marked the 250th anniversary of their city's devastation. They once again recognized Pombal's role in its resurrection, echoing the strains of gratitude first heard in the late 19th century when a massive monument was planned to honor him at the junction of five of the city's boulevards. There, a bronze marquis still surveys the city, monitoring its pulse and regulating the flow of its lifeblood. Silently acknowledging the tribute to his ambition to see Lisbon arise from the ruins, he peers down in haughty approval at the four concentric circles of traffic that flow eternally at his feet.

HEADLINE: The 2 Ferrers: A Plodder in the Polls, a Celebrity on the Street

BYLINE: By DIANE CARDWELL

 BODY:
For Fernando Ferrer, there may be two New Yorks, as he is fond of saying. But there are also two campaigns. 
 In one, which plays out in the polls, among political leaders and on the Sunday morning news programs, Mr. Ferrer's effort is on life support, incapable of rousing itself and headed for an undignified death.
But in the other, a kind of shadow operation that exists along shopping strips, outside subway stations and in church basements, there is a palpable excitement and optimism for Mr. Ferrer, who in this parallel political universe is both a celebrity and an inspiration.
 Flashes of this alternate reality surface in all five boroughs and just about every day. This week, one flash came when more than 300 voters showed up at a Lower East Side community center to meet Mr. Ferrer, and responded to him with wild cheers. Yesterday morning near Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, another was apparent when several New Yorkers on their way into the subway pledged their votes to Mr. Ferrer, including Richard Collie, a neighborhood resident who cited Mr. Ferrer's opposition to the enormous Atlantic Yards development project. 
 And then one evening in Park Slope, Marty Bernstein, an organizer with the Central Brooklyn Independent Democrats, urged a crowd to help Mr. Ferrer because ''it was under this mayor's watch that the N.Y.P.D. ran roughshod over the protesters,'' he said, referring to antiwar demonstrators during the Republican National Convention. ''That's why it's so important to elect Freddy Ferrer and get this bum out of office who's trying to buy the election.''
 And on an afternoon in Corona, Queens, Nurys Sancedo, a hospital worker, waved emphatically at Mr. Ferrer as he rode by on his campaign vehicle, a blue and white school bus reshaped to resemble a flatbed truck. ''People need apartments to live,'' Ms. Sancedo said. ''Many people don't have money to pay a lot of rent. I'm working hard for many, many years, but some people don't work, and they're waiting for a place to live.''
 Indeed, it is moments like these -- when people spontaneously swarm close to shake his hand or when drivers stop traffic to honk their horns and give a thumbs-up -- that allow Mr. Ferrer, as well as his supporters and staff members, to remain game-ready against the throbbing backbeat of doom.
 ''We always say that the most dangerous place to be is a retail walk with Freddy Ferrer,'' said Patrick Gaspard, who oversees the field operation, ''because you're going to get trampled.''
 The state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, noted a similar phenomenon after campaigning with Mr. Ferrer on the Upper West Side on Thursday. ''I can tell by the sensibility out on the street, this is a close race,'' he said.
 But whether that groundswell will be enough to push Mr. Ferrer into contention with Michael R. Bloomberg or over the top on Election Day is an open question. Even those supporters who seem the most animated are also aware of the daunting odds he faces.
 ''I admire him for his work, but I know he's going to lose,'' said Angel Gonzalez of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, who ran across the street yesterday to shake Mr. Ferrer's hand. ''I guarantee he's not going to win. But it's like I tell everybody: You Puerto Ricans, you got to vote for your own kind no matter what. It doesn't make a difference if he's going to win or lose. Stand behind him; maybe he might win, and then he could help you out.''
 Several supporters said the biggest obstacle to Mr. Ferrer is the mayor's checkbook.
 ''The power of money has become so overwhelming that people who you would think would see clearly are sort of having their vision clouded by this vision of 'Maybe his wealth will rub off on me' or something,'' said Gerard Cabrera, a political organizer who lives in Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn. ''But it's infuriating.''
 Nonetheless, he added brightly, he had been feeling discouraged by his candidate's poor showing in opinion polls, but was buoyed by the enthusiastic response he received campaigning for Mr. Ferrer at an arts festival in Dumbo, on the Brooklyn waterfront.
 ''I said, you know, 'Vote for the only Democrat running for mayor,' and I'd get a big smile, or, 'Vote for somebody who isn't trying to buy the election,' '' he said.
 Throughout the city, there are signs that many voters are hearing Mr. Ferrer's message and adopting it as their own. In Brooklyn one morning, Lujira Cooper, a freelance photographer and writer who lives in East Flatbush, said she was planning to vote for him.
 ''I don't like Bloomberg,'' she said. ''I just don't think he's working enough for the folks. We need better education, and I agree with the priorities of not doing social promotion, but I don't believe in the way it was implemented. And the other thing that annoys me is he's signing all of these contracts just before the election,'' she added, referring to labor agreements with city workers. ''To me it doesn't set a good example.''
 Richard Gilliam, an administrator at a Bedford-Stuyvesant substance abuse center, who also said he would vote for Mr. Ferrer, expressed the ambivalence among many Democrats that Mr. Bloomberg has worked to tap. ''I'm not that unhappy with Bloomberg, but on the other hand I think that Freddy may have a better feel for the people,'' he said, echoing Mr. Ferrer's new campaign tagline, ''He's not like Mike. He's more like you.''
 ''Right about now, the way the country is, politically, economically,'' Mr. Gilliam continued, ''we need somebody in New York City with a feel for the city from the roots up.''
 But even politicians and consultants who say Mr. Ferrer is unlikely to win agree that the race is much closer than the polls indicate. And some of his supporters say they think they know why. 
 Alam Morshed, a scientist who lives in Jamaica, Queens, and was holding a sign for Mr. Ferrer in Corona on a drizzly Saturday, said that if Democrats, especially blacks, Asians and Hispanics, come out to vote next Tuesday, Mr. Ferrer should win on the strength of demographics alone.
 Within moments, Mr. Ferrer arrived and, as if to prove Mr. Morshed's point, several Hispanic residents quickly surrounded the candidate, greeting him warmly with cries of ''Democrata,'' or Democrat.
 Whether this alternate reality can trump the one reflected in the polls is a question that will remain unanswered -- until Tuesday.

HEADLINE: The Time Is Wrong for Tax Cuts

 BODY:
Before Hurricane Katrina, Congressional Republicans seemed unstoppable in their drive to cut taxes by an additional $70 billion in the next five years. Now some of the moderates are thinking twice. They fear the cost at a time when the country is already borrowing hundreds of billions of dollars -- most of it from foreigners -- to pay for things like war, hurricane recovery and flu vaccine. And they fear voters' disapproval if they cut taxes for wealthy taxpayers after gutting programs for the poor. (The tax cuts are scheduled to come up just after the current round of spending cuts.) 
 The moderates are right to be wary, especially when the tax-cut die-hards in Congress and the administration keep saying that more tax cuts are vital for continued economic growth after Katrina. That's not so.
In the short term, the economy expands when there's growing demand for all the things that money can buy. Tax cuts increase demand when consumers hold back because of, say, a recession. There's no need for that spur now, but if there were, the right tax cuts would put cash into the hands of people who would otherwise not have much to spend. Tax breaks that mainly benefit the wealthiest, like the special low rates for investment income that Congress is itching to pass, don't fit that description. 
 In the long run, the economy grows when money is invested in ways that increase the nation's capacity to make more goods and provide more services. The money for such investments comes from national savings, which are highly dependent on a healthy federal budget.
 Today's budget is decidedly unhealthy, and more tax cuts will make the big deficits only worse. That's bound to drive up interest rates, making it more expensive for businesses to borrow money. Economists say that will lead to less investment and less growth.
 Tax-cut zealots are also misleading Americans when they imply that they are offsetting reductions in revenue by slashing government spending. These lawmakers have largely spared pork-barrel spending and are instead cutting deeply into programs that foster better health, more education and a stronger infrastructure. Those are precisely the things that are crucial for widespread economic vitality.
 There are many things that could provoke an economic slowdown: the cooling of the housing boom, miserable wage growth, high energy prices and so on. Dropping the tax cuts is not one of them.

HEADLINE: Detroit Gets Its October Sales Numbers and Winces 

BYLINE: By Mark A. Stein

 BODY:
HIGHER energy prices are bruising American automakers, worrying consumers and hobbling manufacturers, as several events made clear this week. But energy costs are not yet causing inflation to accelerate appreciably, the Federal Reserve concluded.

MOTOWN SLOWDOWN -- Automobile sales tumbled in October, with General Motors and Ford hit particularly hard. Sales at each of the two big American-owned carmakers fell more than 25 percent from the month a year ago. Worst hit were their most profitable models, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles.
Sales of these so-called light trucks dropped 30 percent for G.M. and 31 percent for Ford as automakers scaled back the discounts that had helped to offset rising gasoline costs. Sales of the biggest S.U.V.'s, including the Ford Expedition and the Cadillac Escalade XLT, did worse, falling by more than half. So did sales of the Hummer H2, which is so big and inefficient that it is not even classified as a light truck. One pickup sold well last month: the Toyota Tacoma, which gets about 20 percent more miles a gallon than the Ford F-150. Tacoma sales rose 37 percent. 
 Over all, G.M. accounted for 22 percent of domestic automobile sales and Ford for 17 percent. Both are record lows. DaimlerChrysler had 16 percent and Toyota 15 percent.
 Based on worldwide sales, Toyota may overtake G.M. as the No. 1 automaker next year. Toyota is expected to make 9.2 million vehicles in the 2006 calendar year. G.M., which has said it plans to close factories early next year to reduce its costs, is forecast to produce about 9.1 million vehicles.

TAPPING THE BRAKE -- The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 4 percent. It was the 12th quarter-point increase in the last 16 months, and Fed officials announced no change to their longstanding policy of raising rates in small but steady steps.
 The Fed's move came as the Institute for Supply Management reported that the nation's manufacturing activity grew at a slower pace last month as companies wrestled with rising costs for energy and raw materials. The institute's prices index, which measures those prices, rose to 84 percent in October from 78 percent in September.
 The Commerce Department said factory orders fell 1.7 percent in September, though the Institute for Supply Management said the service sector rose more than expected. Employee productivity also jumped, at an annual rate of 4.3 percent. 
 Higher rates may damp consumer spending and encourage saving. Paul A. Volcker, a former Fed chairman, told a forum at Syracuse University that the United States was consuming and investing about 6 percent more than it was producing.
 The Fed is likely to keep raising rates at its next two meetings, in December and January, the last policy meeting before the current chairman, Alan Greenspan, is scheduled to retire.

PAIN RELIEF -- Vioxx did not cause an Idaho postal worker's heart attack in 2001, and the painkiller's maker, Merck, did not improperly market the drug, a state court jury in New Jersey decided. The verdict, in the second of thousands of product liability lawsuits facing Merck, came after a jury in Texas concluded that Merck was liable in the death of a man felled by a heart attack after taking Vioxx. That jury awarded his widow $253 million, a sum reduced to $26 million by a state law capping civil judgments. Merck has vowed to appeal that case.
 About 20 million Americans took Vioxx between 1999 and 2004. Merck stopped selling it after a clinical trial linked the drug to heart attacks and strokes in patients who used it for 18 months or longer. Company documents suggest Merck scientists were worried about Vioxx's potential heart dangers as early as 1997.
 Merck, which is based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., still faces 2,900 suits in New Jersey alone. In all, more than 6,400 lawsuits have been filed against it in state and federal courts, and tens of thousands more are expected.

AIMING TOO HIGH -- Dell, the world's largest PC vendor, said its recent decision to shift away from undercutting competitors' prices and focus instead on higher profit margins was not working. It warned that lower-than-expected revenue and earnings would result, at least in the third quarter.
 Gartner, the research firm, has forecast that global PC shipments will grow 12.7 percent this year, led by laptops and other ''mobile PC's.'' But revenue from PC sales will probably rise by less than 1 percent because consumers and businesses prefer less-expensive models.
 Dell's biggest rival, Hewlett-Packard, will announce its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings Nov. 17. Analysts expect it to report earnings of 46 cents a share, up from 41 cents a year ago.

PAYING THE PIPER -- A pair of companies agreed to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to settle claims that they had deceived investors or customers. Qwest, the primary local telephone provider in 14 states, said it would pay $400 million to settle lawsuits by shareholders who said the company used accounting tricks to inflate its revenue by $3 billion.
 The accounting firm KPMG, meanwhile, agreed to pay $195 million to settle the claims of hundreds of clients who bought certain tax shelters that the Internal Revenue Service later disallowed as abusive.
 The Securities and Exchange Commission is still seeking civil penalties and investor compensation from seven Qwest executives, including the former chief executive, Joseph P. Nacchio, and the former finance chief, Robert S. Woodruff.

HEADLINE: Two Guys Talking About Stocks

BYLINE: By PAUL B. BROWN

 BODY:
BETWEEN them they are worth more than $90 billion, most of it in equities, so when Warren E. Buffett and Bill Gates talk about the stock market it is probably a good idea to listen.
 And what they have to say in the current issue of Fortune is bound to depress those long the market. In almost a throwaway question by Daniel Roth, the two richest men in America were asked: ''Seven years from now will the S.& P. 500 have returned more or less than 10 percent annually?''
Probably less, they both said. 
 ''You're not going to have the G.D.P. in nominal terms grow 5 percent a year and everybody makes 10 percent a year,'' Mr. Buffett said.
 Mr. Gates added: ''There are some clouds out there.'' 
 Any disappointment in their comments, Mr. Buffett added, is probably based on unrealistic expectations.
 ''In the late 1990's, people were looking in their rearview mirror, and they thought God had granted Americans the right to 15 percent a year. Now six or seven years later, people look in the rearview mirror and they see that conventional investments haven't produced remotely anything like that.''
 AT THE MOVIES -- Mr. Buffett and Mr. Gates have more than enough money to buy everyone in America a ticket to the movies. Their combined worth is more than the total worldwide grosses of the 100 most successful movies of all time.
 As part of the issue celebrating its centennial, Variety lists the 100 top-grossing movies of all time.
 Here are the top 10, in millions:



Title	Domestic 	 Overseas	Titanic (1997)	$601	 $1,250	Rings: Return of the King (2003)	 377	 742	Harry Potter: Sorcerer's Stone (2001)	 318	 656	Rings: Two Towers	 342	 585	Star Wars I: Phantom Menace (1999)	 431	 492	Jurassic Park (1993)	 357	 563	Shrek 2 (2004)	 437	 479	Harry Potter: Chamber of Secrets (2002) 	 262	 615	Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)	 315	 557	Finding Nemo (2003)	 340	 526	

There are a couple of things to note about this list. The grosses have not been adjusted for inflation -- which explains why ''The Mummy Returns'' (61st place) ranks higher than ''Gone With the Wind'' (76). And it really is amazing how limited the list is, with the Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings series accounting for 5 of the 10 top-grossing movies of all time.

SAVE THE OCTOPLEX -- You will notice that no movie from 2005 is among the top 10. Although there have been a few huge hits -- like ''Star Wars III: Revenge of the Sith'' and ''War of the Worlds'' -- 2005 over all looks as if it is not going to be a banner box-office year.
 Everybody has a theory: Rising ticket prices; the fact that more and more theaters are playing commercials; the shrinking gap between when a movie is shown in theaters and when it is available in other formats for home viewing. 
 And, there is always a more basic explanation: Most of the movies have not been very good. (Remember ''The Wedding Date''? ''Venom''? ''Stealth''?)
 However, in the current issue of the movie magazine Fade In, Allen B. Ury offers a great idea for increasing ticket sales: Let people pay one price to see as many movies as they like at a multiscreen complex in a given day, a Tuesday perhaps, when box-office receipts are typically low.
 ''Not only would overall revenues increase, but the longer people stay in the theater, the more concessions they are likely to buy.'' 
 If the one-day pass fails to take off, how about returning to the days of the double feature -- or simply making better flicks?

FINAL TAKE -- Negative-calorie soft drinks? It may happen. Men's Health reports in its November issue that at a recent medical conference, Elite FX presented a study that demonstrated its ''caffeinated Celsius diet beverage raised participants' metabolic rates by nearly 15 percent -- three times the boost from another popular diet drink.'' Would that offset a large buttered popcorn at the movies?

HEADLINE: Free Trade Begins at Home

 BODY:
It was 11 years ago that Bill Clinton stood on a stage in Miami flanked by the leaders of 33 North and South American countries and proposed a hemispheric free trade agreement that would stretch from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego. The Free Trade Area of the Americas, to be completed by 2005, would be the largest in the world, encompassing 850 million people with $13 trillion in purchasing power, its backers said. 
 The summit meeting rang with optimistic calls about forging new ties throughout the region. The cold war was over, and with the single exception of Cuba, all of the region's countries were democracies and believers in open markets, and they were listening to the structural reform dictates of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Fast forward to yesterday. President Bush was in Mar del Plata, Argentina, being heckled by protesters, not to mention taunts from the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chavez. Mr. Chavez, who continues to rant and rail against all things Yankee and often accuses the Bush administration of trying to assassinate him, has decided to use the summit meeting to try to drive a stake through the heart of the free trade agreement.
 That is hardly a tall order; the trade pact is not even on the barest of life-support these days. A decade of retrenching in the United States on trade, combined with economic and currency messes in several Latin American countries, particularly Argentina, have left governments with little appetite for opening markets. Many governments south of the border blame the model of free trade, open markets, privatization and fiscal austerity pushed by the United States for the vast increase in social inequality in the region during the past decade.
 It's not surprising, then, that the summit meeting leaders have chosen to focus on more general issues, like employment and democracy. ''Creating Jobs to Fight Poverty and Strengthen Democratic Governance'' is the mouthful that's the theme of this meeting. American and Canadian officials are still pushing the free trade message in the meeting's final communique, but it will clearly be something far more vague than the pact originally intended. 
 Still, a small step is better than no step. Perhaps it's enough that after the last few years of putting Iraq and the Middle East above all else, President Bush is finally paying a small bit of attention to the United States' own hemisphere.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Candidates Go Multilingual

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE

 BODY:

Both candidates for mayor are using foreign-language ads to broaden their reach. An advertisement for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a first in New York City politics: a mayor speaking Mandarin in a campaign commercial to make his case for re-election. It is one of several ads in which the mayor speaks a foreign language, including Urdu, Russian and Cantonese, to plead his case. This ad is running on Chinese-language cable-TV stations. A 30-second television ad for Fernando Ferrer, called ''Aramina,'' in which his wife addresses the audience, is among several Spanish-language ads currently being broadcast. 


PRODUCER -- Squier Knapp Dunn

ON THE SCREEN -- The commercial is a montage of Mayor Bloomberg walking on the street with residents, many of them Asian-Americans, the police putting a handcuffed man into a car, a classroom with children, storeowners on a street, a bulldozer at a construction site. At the end, the mayor says a phrase in Mandarin while standing on a street.

THE SCRIPT -- The narrator says, also in Mandarin, ''Mayor Bloomberg has improved New York City and made it more prosperous. He has successfully taken down gangs and gun violence. The city's crime rate is at a 40-year-low. The city's security is under our control. Greater responsibility and new standards have improved our schools. He has created 62,000 new jobs, which has helped small businesses. Mayor Bloomberg, a mayor for all New Yorkers.'' Mr. Bloomberg then adds, in Mandarin, ''Greater cooperation will bring greater success.''

ACCURACY -- Generally, the ad sticks to the themes of his campaign, and the Bloomberg administration has indeed continued to build on the success of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in reducing crime. The mayor has also imposed new standards on the schools, though his record on the small-business front has come under criticism for the impact of ticket blitzes, and the Ferrer campaign has complained about high minority unemployment.

SCORECARD -- Mayor Bloomberg's Mandarin is difficult to understand, but he must be given credit for trying to speak a language that many English speakers find hard to grasp. For that, he may score points among Asian-Americans, who often feel sidelined by municipal politics, although the mayor has visited Chinatown many times. This commercial, nearly identical to one aimed at Cantonese-speaking and Korean-American voters, addresses immigrants' concerns about crime, education and small businesses. While Mr. Bloomberg is speaking in Mandarin, the commercial flashes the text of his remarks to ensure that his message gets through. JENNIFER 8. LEE

HEADLINE: Changing Course (Perhaps) on Housing

 BODY:
Public outrage over President Bush's mishandling of the Katrina disaster has forced the administration to back away -- if only temporarily -- from a deeply wrongheaded policy on low-income housing. In New Orleans this week, Housing and Urban Development Secretary Alphonso Jackson announced with great fanfare that the government would tear down some of the most unlivable high-density public housing in the country and replace it with model lower-density housing, which will probably serve mixed-income residents. 
 That sounds a lot like Hope VI, a valuable public housing program, created in the 1990's, that the Bush administration has attacked relentlessly. It has tried to eliminate the program's budget for three straight years. If the recent announcement represents a policy shift and not just a public relations tactic, the change would be welcome.
 Hope VI has furnished desperately needed money for communities that have seen their housing blighted by the disastrous high-rise public projects that the nation mistakenly embraced in the 1940's and 50's. By concentrating poverty -- often in places without jobs or decent schools -- these developments eventually killed entire neighborhoods and socially isolated the families who lived in them.
 Congress has thus far prevented the Bush administration from killing Hope VI, but the program has been preserved at a reduced financing level that falls far short of the national need. Perhaps Mr. Bush will now realize that there is a good deal more work to be done -- all over the country -- before the program runs its course. Meanwhile, in New Orleans, community leaders will need to make sure that some portion of the planned new housing is actually affordable for the poor people who will be displaced. Those who won't be allowed to move back should get vouchers for decent housing elsewhere.

HEADLINE: How Thursday Became the New Friday

BYLINE: By Katie Hafner. 
Katie Hafner, a reporter for The Times, is co-author of ''Where Wizards Stay Up Late: The Origins of the Internet.'' Mark Schreiner contributed reporting from Durham, N.C.

 BODY:
CONSIDER the cadences of daily life that result from something as prosaic as a course schedule. This boring bit of housekeeping establishes a campus's circadian rhythms, its bursts of activity and its lulls. It is the master calendar that dictates when plazas fill and when they empty.
 And consider Friday. Most colleges and universities offer fewer classes on Friday, and while freshmen and sophomores might have to take required classes, juniors and seniors can easily schedule their way around the day.
''We have a lot of students who avoid Friday classes like the plague,'' says Dan L. King, general secretary of the American Association of University Administrators and vice president for academic affairs at Rhode Island College. Although he has seen no studies on the point, he considers it safe to say that Friday classes are ''virtually disappearing.''
 While there are still hundreds of Friday classes, particularly at large public universities, significantly fewer meet on Friday than on a campus's busiest day: about 40 percent fewer at Indiana University Bloomington and 50 percent at Arizona State University and the University of California, Irvine. At California State University, Chico, 890 classes are held on Fridays compared to more than 2,500 on Tuesdays. 
 Many students are so accustomed to a four-day week they cannot imagine life any other way. The weekend begins on Thursday night -- known as ''thirstday'' in some circles at the University of Arizona and Arizona State. At Duke, the Malt Liquor Thursday party is a decade-old tradition. Stanford seniors gather for Pub Night at a different bar every Thursday. 
 Friday itself is not necessarily about slacking off: about 50 percent of undergraduates hold part-time jobs, according to the National Center for Education Statistics, and many use Friday for work, internships or community service. They may even hit the library on Sunday. 
 But for many Friday is a day in recovery, spent sleeping past noon. 
 Charles B. Reed, chancellor of the 23-campus California State University system, explains the pattern as he sees it: ''Student don't think they have to study or prep, then it's off to party on Thursday night, then sleep it off on Friday, then do it again Friday night, go to the game Saturday and do it again Saturday night. 
 ''That is not a healthy atmosphere.''
 Although the growing trend of class-free Fridays is a frequent topic of conversation among university administrators, many say that to enforce change would require too drastic a shift. Meddle with a campus's schedule, they say, and you are meddling with its basic metabolism.
 Nonetheless, some campuses have sought to reclaim Friday. Chico State has increased its Friday classes by 6 percent over the last two years, and more are planned for the Cal State system. Clark University in Worcester, Mass., has more than doubled its Friday classes. Last fall, Duke shook the campus culture with a rethinking of its schedule: administrators not only shored up Friday but increased early-morning classes nearly tenfold. 
 Colleges that are pushing back primarily want to free up the midweek crunch of classes. ''There are literally billions of dollars in facilities that sit empty for too many hours of the week,'' says Dr. Reed. But they also hope to nibble at more substantive issues: to stem Thursday night drinking and to reassert that academics are the raison d'etre of a university. 
 ''It's silly to run a university that has four days of classes and have an entire campus full of people who have what those of us who work for a living would call a long weekend,'' says Sandra Hurd, associate provost at Syracuse University. After changing its schedule last year, Syracuse was able to add 76 new courses to its curriculum, including a seminar in forensic science and a course titled ''Intergroup Dialogue on Race and Ethnicity.''
 The modern timetable has emerged gradually. Some educators trace its beginnings to the oil embargo of 1973, when universities compressed schedules to save energy in classrooms. Students came to like the arrangement, and faculty grew complicit, avoiding Fridays when requesting days for their classes. 
 ''It went like this: faculty need Fridays free to do research, have committee meetings, etc.,'' says John N. Gardner, executive director of the Policy Center on the First Year of College in Brevard, N.C. ''And many administrations did not dare remove what had become another entitlement for the faculty.'' 
 And so college life has come a long way from the days when classes routinely met on Saturday mornings. (Or consider the 15th century, when universities were patterned after monastic life and classes began at 6 a.m.) When students matriculated, it was with the understanding that their time was not their own. 
 But over more recent decades the college campus developed a time zone of its own: students are wide awake at 2 a.m., and lunchtime is for eating breakfast. (Residence halls at the California Institute of Technology don't even bother to serve anything until 9:30 a.m.) Now, as colleges jockey for market share, with students the picky customers, the three-day weekend is an expected perk, like high-speed Internet access. Friday has become the ''collegiate day of rest,'' as Aaron Abramowitz, a 21-year-old senior at the University of California, Berkeley, calls it.
 Barry L. Jackson, director of the Drug, Alcohol and Wellness Network at Bloomsburg University in Pennsylvania, believes that to assume young people entering college are ready for a lack of structure is a mistake. Take a high school student who is expected to be in class every morning at 7:50, he says, and then send that same 18-year-old to college, step back and see what happens.
 ''You'd be amazed at the maneuvering these students go through to schedule themselves so they don't have to go to early-morning classes,'' he says. ''A lack of structure assumes these young people are internally self-disciplined, ready to get up at the same time every day and do their work, and what we're finding is that's not true.''
 JASON JANET, an adjunct professor at the Pratt School of Engineering at Duke, teaches introductory robotics at 8:30 a.m. every Wednesday and Friday. The upper-division course is required for some engineering majors. One recent Friday, attendance was higher than usual but still not perfect: 39 of the 46 students showed up. 
 Dr. Janet had some tricks: he had surprised them the previous Friday -- the day before a fall break -- with a pop quiz. He also sets assignment deadlines on Fridays. This particular day, a status report on the students' robotics projects was due and they picked up take-home exams.
 Amit Joshipura, a 21-year-old senior, listened to Dr. Janet's lecture on the ''Denavit-Hartenberg transformation coordinate assignment system'' with the rheumy eyes and rumpled hair that suggest lack of sleep. He wore a T-shirt emblazoned with ''Party Pandas October 13, 2005,'' a party favor from a sorority bash the night before. The Alpha Omicron Pi ''crush'' party, held at a club in Durham, N.C., had begun at about 11 p.m. and wrapped up after 2 a.m. Mr. Joshipura got to his room at 2:30, but before going to sleep he worked on his project status report for Dr. Janet until 4:30 a.m. Less than four hours later, he woke up in time for the 10-minute walk to Dr. Janet's lecture hall. At 8:30 a.m., he turned in his assignment and took his seat.
 One classmate, David Rodriguez, 21, explained later that rather than eliminating Thursday night partying or cutting Friday classes, Duke students are intent on doing it all. The campus ethic: work hard, play hard. 
 But, he added: ''I watch myself. I don't get as wasted as I would otherwise.'' 
 Duke administrators had set out two years ago to insert more Fridays and mornings in the academic calendar. The prime instruction time had narrowed to between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m. in the middle of the week. Classroom capacity was strained, yet on Friday many classrooms sat empty. ''That was an untenable position,'' says Bruce Cunningham, the registrar. ''We couldn't just keep building new classrooms.'' 
 Another concern was the effect the compressed schedule seemed to be having on choice in the curriculum. ''If you have too many classes overlapping and you get too bunched into a relatively narrow range of time periods, you're really depriving students of choice, and that's really the substantive issue,'' says Peter Lange, provost at Duke.
 After months of committee meetings -- and strong resistance from faculty and students -- the change began last fall. With a few exceptions, departments are now allowed to schedule only half their classes in prime time, leading to a 20 percent increase in Friday offerings. And where there were once 14 classes before 9 a.m. there are now 138, a shift that ignores students' biorhythms, the campus newspaper complained. Many popular or required classes also now meet Wednesday and Friday, leaving students with little alternative but to sign up.
 ''I'm not sure it's a solution to Thursday night drinking problems, although I'm sure it has some effect,'' Dr. Lange says. Duke has been working for several years to crack down on drinking on campus. Now students refer to the Old Duke, where three-day fraternity keggers on the quads were common, and the New Duke, where serving alcohol is regulated and the campus pub is no more. 
 Mostly the parties have moved off campus. Thomas Adelman, a 20-year-old sophomore, is the social chairman responsible for one surviving event, Malt Liquor Thursdays, a celebration of the brew open to the entire university. Wayne Manor, a selective on-campus housing group with a community service emphasis, has played host to M.L.T. since 1994. This semester, Mr. Adelman has cultural anthropology and Italian classes on Fridays. He says he never cuts. ''My parents don't pay $40,000 a year for me to skip class,'' he says. ''If they thought that I did cut classes frequently they probably wouldn't be paying that bill.''
 Duke students, he insists, have a five-day workweek. Mr. Adelman turns his mind back to academics on Sunday: ''Right after the games are over, I'm doing homework.''
 Like Duke, Syracuse had the bulk of its classes bunched up between 10 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. in the middle of the week. By moving courses to Friday, it opened up classroom space throughout the rest of the week. Syracuse now has nearly 200 more classes on Friday than it did two years ago. ''We think we're changing the whole academic culture,'' says Deborah Freund, vice chancellor and provost at Syracuse. ''If you want a campus to be a serious academic environment that provokes free and open inquiry, you don't want to except one day from that inquiry.''
 Getting students to show up is another matter. It is not unusual for college class attendance to languish at about 60 percent. Faculty members at Syracuse are telling administrators that students are coming on Fridays. At Duke, Judith Ruderman, vice provost for academic and administrative services, observes, ''I see lots of students around campus as of 8 a.m. or so, which I never saw before.''
 Some educators point out that if a course engages students, they will take it no matter when it occurs. ''There's a very popular drawing class that meets 3 to 5 Friday afternoon, and it's always oversubscribed,'' says Alexander M. Thompson III, dean of studies at Vassar. 
 Others argue that a change of schedule will not change behavior. ''It's never the schedule that gets the student to come or not come to class,'' says Walter Yuen, a professor of mechanical engineering and chairman of the faculty academic senate at the University of California, Santa Barbara, where only 370 of 3,500 classes take place on Friday. ''The serious student is going to study no matter when you schedule an exam, even if it's on Christmas, and the student who wants to party will do that.'' 
 APPROACH the Chico State campus from one direction and you pass Stormy's Off-Broadway Bar & Grill, Madison Bear Garden and the Normal Street Bar. Approach it from another direction and you pass an enclave of fraternity and sorority houses. You also pass Riley's, a favorite drinking spot at Chico State, whose students are known for their ability to party. 
 Alexa Freese, 22, an energetic senior majoring in graphic design, has spent four years in command of her own time. She works eight hours a week waiting tables at Riley's to earn pocket money and has a graphic design internship on campus 10 hours a week. Thursdays are usually ''early'' nights for Ms. Freese: she gets home by 1 a.m. Parties on Friday and Saturday can go until 3 or 4 a.m. She guards her free Fridays jealously, putting in three hours of her internship but otherwise sleeping in and lunching with sorority sisters. She studies on evenings and Sundays, for a dozen hours a week, she says. Her grade point average is a respectable 3.5.
 Losing Fridays to classes would not sit well with Ms. Freese. ''You'd lose a lot of that freedom kids love about college,'' she says. ''It would make it more like high school.''
 Even earnest overachievers at the University of California, Berkeley, demand their down day.
 Late on a recent Thursday afternoon, the Free Speech Movement Cafe on campus was filled with students wrapping up their classes for the week. James Chang, a 19-year-old senior, killed a little time in the cafe before his last class of the week. In the three years that he has attended Berkeley, he has been able to sleep until 1 p.m. most days and had Friday classes only two semesters. He often heads out of town Friday afternoon with the debate team and doesn't return until Sunday, occasionally even Monday. He estimates that he studies only three to four hours a week, depending on exams and assignments.
 But Mr. Chang could hardly be called a slouch. He plans to graduate in December with a degree in political science and a 3.5 G.P.A. 
 Cathy Koshland, vice provost for academic planning and facilities at Berkeley, would welcome more classes on Friday (when 663 meet, compared with 1,184 on Tuesday), if only to ease the burden on classroom space. But faculty members at Berkeley have, by and large, come to expect a free day on Friday, she says. 
 As for the students, the foreshortened week accommodates the juggling Dr. Koshland sees them do -- working at jobs and internships and practicing with sports teams. But she acknowledges that Thursday night drinking remains an issue. 
 A few blocks down Telegraph Avenue from the Free Speech Movement Cafe, Aaron Abramowitz's weekend has begun: he sits at the outdoor bar at Raleigh's and drinks a pint of beer, dividing his attention between friends and the football game on the television above the bar. Sometimes he flies home to Los Angeles on Wednesday night for an extra long weekend, missing ''a bunch'' of Thursday classes. Yet he, too, maintains a G.P.A. of ''3.5 and change'' in his major, philosophy. Mr. Abramowitz estimates he spends 15 hours a week in classes and another 15 studying.
 George D. Kuh has considered this phenomenon as director of the National Survey of Student Engagement, which attempts to quantify what students put into the postsecondary experience. According to the report, the faculty says a full-time student needs to spend 25 hours preparing for class. ''Students study only 13 hours per week on average, and they're still getting good grades,'' says Dr. Kuh, also a professor of higher education at Indiana University. How to account for the discrepancy? Dr. Kuh says grade inflation might play a role or the courses could lack rigor. 
 Mr. Abramowitz spends 25 hours a week partying and watching television. He often doesn't get to sleep until 3 a.m., well after the last bowling alleys, movie theaters and bars have shut for the night. On Fridays and after working a night shift waiting tables, he wakes up in the middle of the afternoon. ''My schedule,'' he concedes, ''is pushing toward a nocturnal state of existence.'' 
 He is all too aware of the big scary workaday world that will start at the cruel hour of 9 a.m. and run five days. ''My sleep schedule is just going to have to change entirely,'' he says. ''I know this.''
 A promising sign: next semester, Mr. Abramowitz will begin the transition out of the cocoon that is college. Two courses he wants to take -- on Descartes and on the philosophy of mathematics -- will meet on Friday. 
 ''I weighed the pros and cons of taking better classes or having a more party-centered schedule,'' he says. ''The classes won out.''

HEADLINE: Home for the Holidays

BYLINE: By Nancy Hass. 
Nancy Hass is a frequent contributor to The Times.

 BODY:
THE poet T.S. Eliot made a good case for April as the cruelest month, but parents of college freshmen might nominate November. For them, Thanksgiving break can mean a cataclysmic clash of memory and desires. 
 ''It's the first time you've seen your kids since they left, and you have all this emotion pent up,'' says Diane Barker, who is still reeling from last year's holiday, when her daughter, Caroline, came home from M.I.T. for the first time. ''You've spent the time they've been gone thinking of all the things you're going to do, all the rituals you're going to enjoy to prove to yourself that everything is the same. But it winds up exploding in your face.''
Ms. Barker, an administrative assistant who lives in Farmingdale, N.Y., figured she and Caroline would have a leisurely dinner with her parents, then spend the next day as they always had: checking out the Christmas windows on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, doing their first bit of holiday shopping and seeing the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall. ''We're the people who take a horse-and-carriage ride through the park, all that corny stuff,'' she says. 
 But Caroline had other ideas. She wanted to see friends, stay out late and sleep till noon. She agreed to see the Rockettes -- her mom already had the tickets -- but only if they made it a quick round trip. 
 ''She was busy with her own dramas,'' says Ms. Barker, who raised her daughter alone. ''It suddenly dawned on me that they didn't revolve around me and revisiting her childhood. I wasn't prepared for that.''
 College administrators and counselors say that variations on Ms. Barker's Thanksgiving letdown are played out nationwide every November. That first Thanksgiving break can be one of the most difficult times in the lives of many students and their parents. 
 ''People think that leaving home to go off to school is the big trauma, but the majority of kids do fairly well adjusting to college by the end of the first month, and their parents start to adjust, too,'' says Laura Kastner, a therapist who is co-author of ''The Launching Years: Strategies for Parenting From Senior Year to College Life.'' ''It's when that break rolls around that reality sets in, that nothing will ever be the same. It's very confrontational, and for a lot of people it's terribly disorienting.''
 At the core of the conflict are often-unspoken expectations on both sides. Parents are still aching over their child's departure as well as the sense that the nurturing stage of their lives is over. To allay that sadness, they focus on Thanksgiving's reassuring rituals -- the elaborate meal, the hang-out time, the late-night leftover pig-out. But students, who have spent the past three months exploring new intellectual and social terrain and reveling in the freedom of dorm life, often find it impossible to step back into their old roles.
 ''We pretty much spent the whole four days snarling at each other,'' says Sarah Fields of Indianapolis, recalling the tension of being home from Purdue last Thanksgiving. ''Anything I wanted to do -- see friends, sleep, just chill out -- they got this really disappointed look. They wanted to trot me around like a show dog. I know they're proud of me, but really, I wasn't into it. I just wanted to veg out.'' 
 Some conflicts are easily anticipated. Siobhan Counihan of Monroe, N.Y., got her nose pierced as soon as she got to the State University of New York campus in Buffalo last September, and on Halloween pierced her tragus, the cartilage at the front of her ear. ''Before Thanksgiving, I basically received an e-mail from my stepfather demanding that I remove the piercing and telling me to 'rest assured that any of the turmoil and stress this family experiences this holiday will be all your fault,''' she recalls. ''That pretty much set the tone for a horrible experience.''
 Therapists and college counselors say that such conflicts can ultimately prove healthy, but Ms. Kastner says that parents must take the lead: ''It's up to them to set the tone. It's often they who are clinging to the past, which causes a lot of the problem. Their intentions are good, but they need to recognize that their kids have changed profoundly and will continue to do so.''
 Parents tend to forget that three months is an eternity to an 18-year-old, enough time to start becoming a different person. Coming home is a way to try out that new persona. ''Students want people to see the changes, for good or bad,'' says Marjorie Savage, director of the Parent Program at the University of Minnesota and author of ''You're on Your Own (but I'm Here if You Need Me): Mentoring Your Child During the College Years.'' 
 Ms. Kastner says, ''They have to create conflict to differentiate, to drive you apart. ''They announce that they've decided not simply to become an economist, but to become a Marxist economist. Or they're bisexual.'' 
 The impact of these changes is exacerbated by the shortness of the break; a long weekend is rarely enough time for parents to adjust to a pierced nose. Adding to the stress is the fact that most students will have exams when they return. 
 But what seems to rankle parents most is that their children want to spend little of their break time reconnecting with mom and dad. ''She never wanted to see us. Never,'' says Lisa Ryan, a marital therapist from Weston, Conn., whose 19-year-old daughter, Amanda Ziobro, is now a sophomore at George Washington University in Washington. ''It hurts your feelings.''
 Experts say it is important for parents to understand that seeing friends is more than just an excuse to party; it's a crucial step in the creation of identity. ''They discover that some friends must be left behind because they aren't growing and changing,'' says Dale Atkins, a New York City psychotherapist who specializes in family relationships. ''They need to have left and come back to see those people clearly. It can be very painful, and parents can help by giving them plenty of space to do that work.''
 But even the most understanding parents are challenged by one change: their children have become nocturnal creatures. 
 ''The average time that students go to sleep on the weekends is 3 a.m.,'' says Ms. Kastner. ''Their average waking time is noon. And there are their parents, standing over them at 9 a.m. the morning after Thanksgiving, telling them that they're missing the best part of the day.''
 Curfew is a major source of conflict, too. ''It's common for parents to give what I call the 'When You're Under My Roof' speech and insist on enforcing the same curfew that existed when the kid was in high school, which almost always results in a blowup,'' Ms. Kastner says. 
 Ms. Ryan concedes that she assumed her old midnight curfew would stand during the Thanksgiving break. ''I was horrified when on Wednesday night at 11, right after my daughter got in from Washington, she starting getting ready to go out. I said, 'How are you going to be able to get back in half an hour?' Then I realized she had no intention of coming back by midnight.'' 
 Midway through her lost Thanksgiving weekend, just after the rushed trip to see the Rockettes, Diane Barker had a revelation, one that she has contemplated with a degree of melancholy over the past year. ''It's pretty simple,'' she says. ''I realized I had to suck it up.''

Extreme Makeover, Home Edition
 ACCORDING to college counselors and family therapists, there are ways to make Thanksgiving break less excruciating.

EXPLORE EXPECTATIONS BEFOREHAND In mid-November, ask about your child's plans, specifically how much time will be spent with family. Discuss a curfew.

KEEP EXPECTATIONS LOW It's reasonable to expect your child to have Thanksgiving dinner with family, but you're in uncharted waters after that.

ASK ABOUT CHANGES Emerging adults are bound to alter their appearance and habits, and you don't want to learn your daughter is a vegetarian as you slice the turkey. And make sure to reciprocate. If you've turned your son's bedroom into a workout room, this is the time to warn him.

BE INTERESTED Try to seem engaged in the changes. When she returns with a pierced navel or he declares he's a Buddhist, ask sincere, unbiased questions instead of making snide comments.

DON'T TALK ABOUT HIM When your child is sitting right there, don't use the third person. Don't say to your guests, ''Did you know she's taking two courses in human sexuality?'' or push him to regale friends and relatives with college stories.

CREATE NEW RITUALS They should acknowledge your child's new maturity and independence. This is a new time in both your lives. NANCY HASS

HEADLINE: If at First You Don't Succeed Enough

BYLINE: By Abigail Sullivan Moore. 
Abigail Sullivan Moore contributes to the Connecticut section of The Times.

 BODY:
THIS fall at Avon Old Farms, a prestigious boys' prep school in Connecticut, 16 percent of the freshmen are transfer students doing the year for the second time. They include three straight-A students, says Brendon Welker, its director of admissions. 
 Repeating the year -- in some circles known as a ''refresh'' or ''resoph,'' depending on the grade -- has become an increasingly accepted practice at private schools in the Northeast, especially boarding schools. At St. Paul's School in New Hampshire, 22 percent of the freshman class have transferred in to repeat the year, as have 6 percent of sophomores. At Kent School, also in Connecticut, 11 percent of juniors are doing the same.
 Traditionally, a small percentage of students have repeated a grade to allow them time to mature or to fill in subject gaps. Boys have done it much more than girls, often at the school's bidding. Some students have taken an extra year just to improve in sports. But many of today's repeaters are motivated by the intense competition for admission to elite colleges. They want to bolster already good academic transcripts with better grades, a richer roster of Advanced Placement courses and the extracurricular activities that colleges like to see, school officials say. 
 To make their offspring look even more appealing, some parents are not sending transcripts from that ''first'' ninth grade to colleges, an omission that raises ethical issues. Their hope is that admissions officers won't see the stutter, says Marcia Rubinstien, an educational consultant in West Hartford, Conn., who advocates honesty.
 ''Five or 10 years ago, students didn't repeat unless there was something broke that needed to be fixed, a presiding academic deficit, an illness or some disturbance in the family pattern,'' says Gregg Maloberti, dean of admissions at the Lawrenceville School in New Jersey. In 2001, only a single student out of 150 incoming freshmen there was repeating the year; last fall 15 did it. This year, the school admitted 11 freshman repeaters. 
 Mike Hirschfeld, admissions director at St. Paul's, has seen a noticeable increase. ''Parents want their kids to be successful, and if they believe repeating will enhance their chances, they will absolutely consider it,'' he says. In the past five years, a third of the graduates of St. Paul's received at least one offer from an Ivy League school. 
 Of course, other factors influence the decision, like fears that public high schools aren't giving their children the best education. Families also want to make sure their children are mature enough to take advantage of the advanced curriculum at these private schools, and to succeed when the bar is so high. 
 The practice leaves some college gatekeepers in an ethical quandary. While supporting the idea of giving students time to do better, administrators fret about the equity of a strategy available only to the ambitious affluent, those who can pay $25,000 to $35,000 a year.
 ''The ones who can do this are only the ones who can afford to do this,'' says Jim Bock, dean of admissions and financial aid at Swarthmore College. ''Where does that leave the rest of the people?'' 
 For moderate-income families seeking a similar advantage, and those in public schools, the answer is probably nowhere. 
 At New Trier, a rigorous public high school on Chicago's affluent North Shore, repeating a grade to shore up a solid transcript is out of the question. ''The answer is unequivocally no, never has happened and I would not support it,'' says Hank Bangser, the superintendent. 
 Some private schools aren't going along either. At Thayer Academy in Braintree, Mass., officials say they were amazed recently when a handful of its current upper-class students asked to repeat. Thayer refused, fearful of seeding the practice.
 School officials and consultants who help place children in top private schools know it's a hot topic among parents. ''There's a big ripple effect,'' says Andrew Bogardus, director of admissions for Berkshire School in Sheffield, Mass. ''Families are talking about their plan of attack for education, and college admissions is driving it. If someone has a successful plan, they'll talk about it.'' 
 One Westchester County mother credits her daughter with the idea of repeating sophomore year at a New England boarding school. Then a B student in a competitive public high school, she was feeling pressured about college admissions and knew another repeater. The parents talked to families who had found success with the strategy. 
 ''The parents say things like, 'This was the best thing that I did,''' says the mother, who did not want to be identified for fear of hurting her daughter's reputation. ''She could be a B-plus student,'' she says, adding that an extra year of smaller classes and developing study skills would better prepare her for college, although probably not the Ivy League. ''Why rush?'' Meanwhile, the daughter feels a ''wonderful reprieve,'' she says. ''It's a gift we gave her.'' 
 Many people outside the world of private schools still view repeating a grade as something to hide. William M. Shain, dean of undergraduate admissions at Vanderbilt University, worries about the effect on an adolescent's self-esteem. He says it suggests ''you're not good enough yet -- you should go back in the oven.'' 
 But independent school administrators and students insist it carries no stigma within their ranks. 
 ''People have a certain stereotype about repeating a year -- they think your grades aren't good enough,'' says Peter Hafner, who transferred from a private school in Bethesda, Md., to the Taft School in Connecticut, where he repeated his junior year to be more competitive in academics and athletics. 
 Yet at Taft, ''I didn't feel funny,'' he says. ''It was a rare occasion when people didn't understand the dynamics.'' Once considered a bit shy, Mr. Hafner blossomed with a clean slate. He took Advanced Placement calculus, history, economics and other honors classes. He served on student government and played hockey so well that Harvard recruited him. 
 Mr. Hirschfeld of St. Paul's confirms Mr. Hafner's perception. Instead of taking a negative view, he says, his students have the attitude, '''Wow! I can take a second year of calculus.''' 
 Those who repeat sophomore or junior year in a different school are easy for college admissions officials to spot: students need to show records for freshman through senior year, so the officials get transcripts from both schools. Those who repeat freshman year, though, may not send transcripts from the first school. 
 ''Families aren't always comfortable with disclosing an unusual situation,'' Ms. Rubinstien says. ''They are going to want to sterilize that application.''
 Steve Thomas, admissions director at Colby College, believes he wouldn't be fooled. ''You can't effectively erase a year to a sharp reader and if you do, the flags go up,'' he says. Any hint of deception is bad news for an applicant. Acknowledging that year, though, brings added scrutiny from admissions officers.
 Considering prep school tuition, some college administrators see repeating as an expensive investment with an uncertain return. Overloading transcripts with Advanced Placement courses may give an applicant an overly groomed feel, unwittingly undermining the student's chances at colleges that pride themselves on admitting bright, risk-taking individuals. 
 Says Dick Steele, interim dean of admissions for Bowdoin College, ''I sure would expect a pretty darn good year with that chance.''
