HEADLINE: Missing General Managers Are Not on the Agenda, but Baseball People Do Talk

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
THEY'LL be handing out scorecards tomorrow at the annual general managers meetings at the Hyatt Grand Champions Resort and Spa in Indian Wells, Calif. Couldn't tell many of the teams' general managers without them.
 In alphabetical order, by clubs, Arizona will have Josh Byrnes; Baltimore, Mike Flanagan (along with the new assistant Jim Duquette); Philadelphia, Pat Gillick; Tampa Bay, Andrew Friedman and Gerry Hunsicker; and Texas, Jon Daniels.
The Red Sox and the Dodgers will have blank spaces in the scorecard, but their seats at the table won't be empty. Having lost or disposed of their general managers in the past week, the Red Sox and the Dodgers will be represented by lower-level functionaries. But the departed general managers, Theo Epstein and Paul DePodesta, will most likely be the hottest topics of conversation in the off hours of the meetings.
 The Dodgers dismissed the 32-year-old DePodesta two years into a five-year contract. Epstein, 31, walked away from a three-year, $4.5 million contract offer from the Red Sox. The Dodgers said they expected to have a new general manager this week. The Red Sox have said nothing about their plans. 
 The Red Sox, in fact, haven't said much about anything. Epstein held a news conference last Wednesday but didn't really explain why he left the team. Larry Lucchino, the chief executive officer, didn't attend the news conference and still wasn't talking at week's end. ''I don't think he's calling anyone now,'' his secretary said Friday. ''As far as I know, he's still in radio silence.''
 Despite the absence of public explanations, baseball circles were filled with talk about the stunning development. The baseball grapevine is a remarkable conduit for information. Someone always hears something about everything.
 In this instance, the talk was about a major blowup between Epstein and Lucchino last weekend. Epstein's desire for autonomy in his player personnel decisions was said to be at the heart of the blowup. 
 Epstein, whom Lucchino nurtured in San Diego and Boston before making him the Red Sox general manager, wanted much the same thing as Brian Cashman sought before agreeing to stay with the Yankees. 
 Cashman was apparently assured he would control the club's New York-Tampa axis, but having last week's organizational meetings in New York instead of Tampa does not guarantee Cashman future control.
 In seeking to be his own man, Epstein felt he had outgrown Lucchino and wanted to get out from under what he felt was Lucchino's suffocating oversight. Lucchino was willing -- reluctantly -- to give Epstein the money he wanted but wasn't about to relinquish the control he felt was his as team president. 
 In addition, Epstein was upset with Charles Steinberg, the executive vice president for public affairs for the Red Sox. Steinberg was conspicuously absent from the Epstein news conference, lending credence to that aspect of the story. For Epstein to turn on Steinberg is especially strange because Steinberg was perhaps more responsible for his career than Lucchino.
 Steinberg hired Epstein as a public relations intern in Baltimore, took him to San Diego, then steered him to law school with the idea of getting him into baseball operations after he graduated. 
 Like Lucchino, Epstein and Steinberg did not return calls seeking clarification of the circumstances of Epstein's departure.
 Epstein told people that he had no privacy in Boston and that he couldn't even go out to dinner.
 The Red Sox will have four representatives at the meetings -- Peter Woodfork, baseball operations director; Jed Hoyer, assistant general manager; Ben Cherington, player development director; and Craig Shipley, special assistant to the general manager.
 In the absence of a general manager, the Dodgers will have Kim Ng, vice president and assistant general manager, and Roy Smith, vice president for scouting and development.
 Gillick will be attending the meetings in his fourth incarnation as a general manager. At 68, he is older than the departed Epstein and DePodesta combined and older than the newcomers Daniels (28) and Byrnes (35) combined. Byrnes served most recently as Epstein's assistant in Boston, where he might have succeeded Epstein had he not taken the Arizona job three days earlier.
 Flanagan was sort of a co-general manager with Jim Beattie, though neither had the title. Peter Angelos, the Orioles' owner, doesn't like the title general manager. Now Flanagan has replaced Beattie as executive vice president for baseball operations, and Duquette has been given Flanagan's title of vice president for baseball operations.
 Friedman, a baseball neophyte, and Hunsicker, a veteran general manager, are part of a Tampa Bay experiment in redefining the traditional front office.

Possibilities in Boston
 Before ''creating'' Theo Epstein in Boston, Larry Lucchino did the same thing in San Diego with Kevin Towers, taking a young executive and making him general manager. The Red Sox have a group of young executives from whom Lucchino could pluck his newest general manager, but they have two more intriguing possibilities.
 Jerry Kapstein is a senior adviser on baseball matters in their front office and has been a longtime associate of Lucchino, beginning in San Diego. People who know both men say they could work together without getting in each other's way. 
 If Kapstein's name is familiar, it's because he was the first major player agent, representing many of the players in the first group of free agents in 1976. Kapstein left the agent business in 1989 before becoming the Padres' chief executive the next year. 
 His tenure was short-lived, though, ending two months later when his wife, Linda, daughter of Joan Kroc, the Padres' owner, filed for divorce. 
 If the Red Sox don't want to be that radical, they could consider Lou Piniella, who is unemployed at the moment. Piniella was the Yankees' general manager for eight months before returning to the dugout as manager in June 1988. His presence at Fenway Park would defuse the uproar over Epstein's departure. 

The Ramirez Question
 What's to become of Manny? What's to become of the Red Sox if they are forced to trade Manny? Though his agent declined to confirm it, Manny Ramirez wants the Red Sox to trade him. ''I've had some conversations with the club about Manny's situation,'' Greg Genske, the agent, said, acknowledging nothing else. 
 Ramirez's status is simply another problem confronting the Red Sox. But the way they deal with it could be every bit as critical as the way they fix their vacancy in the general manager's chair. Omar Minaya, the Mets' general manager, has had his eye on Ramirez for the past year, but Ramirez has veto rights over a trade and has told at least some people that he won't play in New York. 
 ''That's an overstatement,'' Genske said. ''He hasn't ruled it out. He hasn't ruled out anything. We've had very preliminary conversations with the Red Sox..''
 Ramirez might have floated the idea that he wouldn't play in New York to set up a contract extension if the Mets did want to trade for him.

Yankees' Silent Upheaval
 When George Steinbrenner fires a coach during the season, it causes a huge uproar. The Yankees just turned over nearly their entire coaching staff, and it raised nary a sound. Luis Sojo, the third-base coach the past two seasons, was demoted to a minor league managing job, and Roy White, the first-base coach the past two seasons, was fired. 
 ''We wanted to upgrade, and those were areas we felt we needed to improve,'' General Manager Brian Cashman said.
 Joe Torre wanted Ron Guidry to replace the retired Mel Stottlemyre as pitching coach, but Cashman, concerned about Guidry's inexperience, preferred Joe Kerrigan. They went with Guidry and made Kerrigan the bullpen coach.

HEADLINE: Profits Up at City's Hotels; So Are Tensions

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Hotels in Manhattan are booming. Rates are high and profits are rolling in. 
 But seven months before the industry's contract with union workers is due to expire, no one is talking about what promises to be a record year for the city's tourism industry.
Instead, hotel managers and labor leaders are rumbling about the possibility of a strike or lockout come July 1 that could shut down most of the city's 315 hotels, from the Waldorf-Astoria to the Marriott Courtyard at La Guardia Airport, and could idle 28,000 workers. 
 The industry association's lawyers, Kane Kessler, issued a memo on Oct. 12 warning members that the union was seeking ''far-reaching and radical changes.'' The memo sought to bind members to a seven-page ''mutual assistance pact,'' which requires absolute loyalty if the industry decides to impose a ''bargaining lockout in order to obtain a negotiated settlement.'' 
 At the same time, the New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council, an umbrella group for hotel unions that is putting together a $30 million strike fund, has been working hard to subvert the industry's unity. 
 Peter Ward, president of the council, said he had signed secret ''me too'' agreements with more than two dozen hotel operators, in which they promised to keep their doors open and their employees working if contract talks broke down. 
 It is hard to tell whether all the talk is part of the routine warm-up to contract talks or a sign of a coming confrontation.
 But it comes at a time when the main hotel union, Unite Here, has aligned labor contracts in six major cities -- New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Boston, Honolulu and Toronto -- to expire next year to put pressure on global hotel operators like Hilton, Starwood and Marriott. 
 ''The only way an industry can show strength against a union is by forming a united front,'' said John Fox, senior vice president at PKF Consulting, a hotel specialist. ''Nothing unusual there. But I do think the union's going to take a tough stance. Where this shakes out, I don't know. We're still in the early posturing stages.''
 The economic conditions for the hotel industry in New York have never been better. The average occupancy rate at Manhattan hotels in the first nine months of this year was 84.8 percent, meaning that on many days the borough's 63,000 hotel rooms are sold out. 
 At the same time, the average room rate jumped 14 percent over last year, to $213.64. Analysts expect that by the end of December, the average will exceed the record $223 a night set in 2000.
 ''We're at record levels of occupancy,'' said Kirk Reed, who oversees hotel consulting in New York for PricewaterhouseCoopers. ''We'll reach a new peak level for the average daily rate by the end of the year.''
 Vijay Dandipani, chairman of the Hotel Association of New York City, played down the tough talk and the possibility of a strike or lockout, which could deal a severe blow to the city's tourism industry. 
 ''As far as the city of New York goes, we have not had a major issue in several contract negotiations,'' said Mr. Dandipani, chief operating officer of Apple Core Hotels, a chain of five budget hotels. ''Sometimes they've been contentious, but it never reached a flash point.''
 Joseph Spinnato, the president of the hotel association, said that the idea of a ''mutual assistance pact'' now circulating among hotel operators has been used in the past and does not represent a new level of hostility toward the union. It is intended to ensure that the unions cannot strike one hotel at a time.
 ''A reasonable wage increase is always in order,'' Mr. Spinnato said. ''I don't know of any outstanding major problems that could not be resolved by negotiation.''
 But Mr. Ward described the pact as disturbing. He said a sympathetic hotel manager had provided a union member with a copy of the document. It requires operators who sign the agreement to act in unison if they decide to lock out union workers, even if they disagree with the tactics adopted by the majority of the group. Hotels that break ranks and sign a separate agreement with the union are subject to fines.
 Mr. Ward said that wages and reduced workloads would be issues in the upcoming negotiations. He also called for sanctions against hotel operators that repeatedly violated union contracts. He said that at the Hilton, the largest hotel in the city, the union had won more than $2.3 million in back pay for members.
 If workers can be fired for taking a shampoo bottle out of a hotel, he asked, why should managers who continually violated the contract not be fired? 
 There is also a broader, more activist strategy at work for the union.
 ''We recognize that we're dealing with multinational corporations that think and act globally all the time,'' Mr. Ward said. ''We've reached a point where we have to think and act nationally in order to further our interests. We're not prepared to sit back any longer to have a poverty-level contract in one city and a better contract in this city.''
 Ian Schrager, who created the Royalton and Morgan hotels and will soon open the Gramercy Park Hotel, said it would be difficult for the industry to close ranks in New York. He has already signed a me-too agreement with the union.
 ''It's going to be hard to have a united front,'' Mr. Schrager said. ''Everyone always caves in. Even some big companies have signed a me-too agreement with the unions.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: A scene outside the New York Hilton, at 54th Street and Avenue of the Americas, on Friday. The city's average room rate is nearing a record set in 2000, $223, and the Manhattan occupancy rate is 84.8 percent. (Photo by Robert Stolarik for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Monopoly's Money

BYLINE: By ANDREW ZIMBALIST. 
Andrew Zimbalist is the Robert A. Woods Professor of Economics at Smith College and the author of ''In the Best Interests of Baseball? The Revolutionary Reign of Bud Selig,'' to be published in March by Wiley.

 BODY:
Never mind the drivers, Nascar's rulers seem to be spinning out of control. A few weeks ago, Nascar's chairman and chief executive, Brian France, proposed a plan to limit the number of cars that team owners could control to three. This could reduce the stable of cars owned by Roush Racing, which has five, and Hendrick Motorsports, which has four. 
 France says he is concerned about equity and competitive balance. As the argument goes, when one owner controls several cars, the drivers can share information about track conditions and car technology, giving them an advantage over other drivers. And as it becomes more and more expensive to build cars and sponsor teams, owners with less capital will suffer, as will the fortunes of their drivers. 
It is nice to see that France, who may soon be leaving the family business, has discovered an interest in competition and fairness. His family, after all, owns Nascar, the Motor Racing Network (the radio network that broadcasts all Nascar races) and Americrown (the catering company that sells food at most Nascar tracks); it also owns a share of Action Performance (the dominant motor car memorabilia company) and owns a controlling interest in the publicly traded International Speedway Corporation. 
 The corporation owns 12 of the 22 racetracks that are host to the Nextel Cup, Nascar's premier series. It also has economic ties to the owner of another five tracks where Nextel Cup races are run.
 The only new tracks Nascar has sanctioned for Cup races since 1998 are owned by the speedway corporation. One of the most modern and well-equipped tracks in the country, Kentucky Speedway, has been trying to get a Cup race for the past five years. Nascar has put off Kentucky each year. Meanwhile, Nascar races at inferior and more dangerous tracks owned by the speedway corporation. 
 What about large teams with multicar entries? From 1990 to 1995, only 7 percent of all entries were from multicar teams. This proportion grew to 38 percent from 2000 to 2004. 
 Yet as multicar teams became more prominent, the outcome of races has become more balanced. During the past five years, no driver has repeated as the top earner or the points champion. From 1990 to 1994, there was an average of 12 different winners a season; from 2000 to '04, there was an average of 17 different winners a season.
 Multicar owners also seem to make it easier for new drivers to enter the top circuits. As the expenses associated with building and maintaining a racecar skyrocket, individual drivers or car owners increasingly find the cost prohibitive. The economies of scale associated with multicar teams facilitate new entries.
 So what is France really worried about? About 25 percent of Nextel race revenue is paid to the drivers and their teams. This compares with the more than 50 percent of revenue paid to players in the National Football League, the National Basketball Association, the National Hockey League and Major League Baseball. Nascar is earning a bundle by being the monopoly sanctioning agency, then controlling the production process. 
 If the drivers are united by multicar teams, Nascar will lose some of its leverage over the producers. The Roush and Hendricks teams, for instance, could come together and boycott certain Nextel Cup events if the drivers and teams are not offered a larger share of the spoils. Worse still, they could threaten to form a new racing circuit. 
 They may also begin to demand that races be transferred to the more modern and longer tracks that are not owned by the speedway corporation. And if race sites were selected based on merit rather than on ownership, the profits of the Nascar/International Speedway Corporation cartel would shrink. If France were truly concerned about new drivers getting a fair shake, there would be a straightforward solution. The Cup series today has 36 official races. France says he is reluctant to expand the number because drivers need time off. 
 Fair enough. Nascar could mandate that each driver be limited to 36 official races a year, but still sanction, say, 45 Nextel Cup races. That would be a 25 percent expansion in the number of races and potential entries -- and new drivers would have a greater opportunity to win.
 Nascar output would expand to new tracks and new regions of the country. Higher output and service to new areas would improve consumer satisfaction. It would be a victory for fans, for drivers, for independent track owners and for the economies of new regions. The only loser would be the France family.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Brian France, Nascar's chief executive, said competitive balance was his concern when he proposed limiting the number of cars team owners could control. (Photo by Terry Renna/Associated Press)

LENGTH: 1859 words

HEADLINE: Reserved

BYLINE: By Roger Lowenstein. 
Roger Lowenstein is a contributing writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
Power, as Jimmy Breslin once wrote, is the illusion of power. Few are more dependent upon cultivating the illusion than the chairman of the Federal Reserve. After the last mostly prosperous 18 years, no economic figure in the world is thought to be as influential as Alan Greenspan. Every blessing that has befallen America -- impressive growth rate, high productivity, low inflation -- is laid at Greenspan's door. So, too, our periodic misfortunes, like the occasional bubble or bust or the recent inflationary uptick. Senator John McCain once joked that if he were elected president and Greenspan were to die, he would prop him in his chair and hope no one noticed. But is it possible that no one would notice -- that prosperity, or sound monetary management, at any rate, would go on?
The most oracular and idiosyncratic of Fed chairmen, Greenspan has personalized the office like no one before. But while he has been issuing those Delphic pronouncements, a funny thing has happened to central banking. It has become more normative -- less an art and more a discipline. Central bankers have gotten better. They have also gotten luckier. 
 When Greenspan's reign began in August 1987, long-term interest rates touched 9 percent. Today they are half that. It challenges credulity to think a single man could have fashioned such a tectonic shift. After all, long-term rates and inflation have also fallen in every other highly industrialized country (though their economies did not grow as quickly as ours). Greenspan, like other bankers, rode a forgiving current as nations regulated less and traded more. World economies benefited from the software revolution and, until recently, falling energy prices. And each central bank, including the Fed, was tugged along the path of monetary discipline by its neighbors. In a closed economy, in which only dollars matter, the Fed alone could regulate liquidity; in a global economy, it must collaborate. This is why Greenspan has been exhorting China to revalue -- and why he needs London and Frankfurt to avoid inflation almost as much as Washington. It may bruise American pride to think of Ben S. Bernanke, nominated to succeed Greenspan, as resembling another dully professional Eurobanker, but that image may be closer to his future than that of the man pulling the levers behind the curtain.
 Before Congress created the Federal Reserve System in 1913, America did rely on monetary wizards -- often J.P. Morgan -- to bail it out of panics. The Fed was meant to replace them, to be a banker of last resort. Also, the country wanted to free itself from relying on the Bank of England to finance its agricultural exports. But the notion of limited power was inherent in the Fed's creation. Farm states were wary of letting Eastern bankers control the money supply; thus, Congress established a network of semiautonomous regional banks. The chairman of the Fed is, in this network, merely the first among equals, one of seven governors who preside over the federal system.
 For years, he was barely even that. During the 1930's, the Fed was blamed for either causing or deepening the Great Depression. To diminish its potential for further mischief, Franklin Roosevelt turned it into the handmaiden of the Treasury Department. During World War II, the Fed meekly agreed to keep interest rates at 2.5 percent, thus letting Treasury finance the war at a price of its own choosing. President Truman reluctantly acknowledged the Fed's need for autonomy, but the deed came slower than the pledge. 
 In 1965, after voting to bump up interest rates, William McChesney Martin Jr., the only Fed chairman to hold the job longer than Greenspan, was summoned to Lyndon Johnson's ranch and accused of putting himself above the presidency. According to Robert P. Bremner, Martin's biographer, Martin was subjected to the classic Johnson punishment: a hair-raising ride at 60 miles per hour over dirt roads with the president at the wheel. L.B.J.'s demeaning treatment reflected Martin's more subservient view of his job (you could scarcely imagine Greenspan submitting to such humiliation). He failed to pursue a tight money policy when it counted, and by the time he retired, in 1970, inflation was 6 percent and beginning to escalate out of control.
 Even a truly ''independent'' chairman cannot act alone. He has only one of 12 votes on the Federal Open Market Committee, the body that sets the ''federal funds'' rate -- the interest rate that banks charge for overnight loans. A Fed chairman who cannot command an overwhelming majority of his fellow governors, as well as of the regional bank presidents, will be perceived as weak, and so will his policy. When Paul Volcker was appointed Fed chairman in 1979, inflation was raging. In his first attempt to raise rates, he suffered a split vote. The market reacted badly. Inflation depends on expectations; to stop raising prices, business needed to be sure that the Fed chief was truly in charge. 
 Volcker quickly gained wide respect and decisively broke the inflationary spiral. He put the country through two rough recessions in the process. This suggests another limitation on the Fed's power: its principal weapon is rather blunt. In theory, when the Fed tightens or loosens the overnight rate, the impact courses through the economy, affecting the rates available to corporations, homeowners, credit-card holders and so forth, over both the short and long terms. But the process is indirect and not always effective.
 Given that the Fed is trying to regulate a complex modern economy -- everything from mortgage rates to industrial output to the stock market to employment -- the federal funds rate is a rather imprecise tool. To be even somewhat successful, the chairman has had to rely on unwritten powers and influence people's expectations. In particular, he has had to impress the bond market, for it is bond traders who set long-term interest rates, which have a more direct impact on investment and economic growth.
 In 1987, only two months into the job, Greenspan faced a daunting hurdle to managing expectations -- a stock-market crash. The next morning he issued a terse statement proclaiming the readiness of the Fed to ''provide liquidity.'' Lou Crandall, chief economist of Wrightson ICAP, a bond market research firm, says he wondered: ''Yeah? Like how?'' No less than inflation, ''liquidity is a state of mind,'' according to Crandall. ''Once it is lost, the Fed has no magic wand to bring it back.''
 People cannot be forced to invest, and no one who lacks faith in the system will do so. After the crash, the highly unlikely rumor spread that the Fed was buying stocks. The rumor was not unhelpful. People believed that Greenspan was doing something. And so, they recommenced to take risk.
 Greenspan has been especially adroit at using the power of the pulpit to heighten his seeming omnipotence. The chairman appears before Congress, twice a year, to expound on the condition of the economy. There and in his other public appearances, he has mastered a syntax at once knowing and a trifle obscure. Unlike other officials -- even the president -- he is not subjected to press conferences or public interviews, where he might seem diminished. The Fed chairman also sits at the helm of a remarkable information network and an awesome organization. He feeds off some 200 economists, who pounce on every bit of economic news, every speech by a corporate C.E.O., and digest and analyze their significance. Each Monday, he convenes his fellow governors so that each may share his or her outlook. It is only then, having received the collective wisdom as to the state of America's economy, that the chairman proposes a policy response. ''One reason his pronouncements are viewed so heavily,'' says Kevin Hassett, a former Fed economist now with the American Enterprise Institute, ''is he really does know the most about what's going on of anyone on earth.''
 The disinclination to vote against Greenspan is considerable, but the board's near-unanimity in recent years has been based on more than a cult of personality. According to Alice Rivlin, a governor during the Greenspan era, the times when the chairman had to twist arms were few. One was in the mid-90's, when he recognized that computers were making workers more productive. Sooner or later, however, the board would have arrived there without him. Although Greenspan is famously unconventional, willing to examine the most unusual data, the dirty secret about central banking is that, more and more, consensus, not personal idiosyncrasy, prevails. By making the workings of the Fed more transparent, Greenspan has ensured that the Fed's mystique will fade, and that in the post-Greenspan era, personality will matter even less.
 Nowadays, markets rarely move when the Fed takes action, because its actions are anticipated. There is simply more agreement among economists over what the Fed should and will do. In lay terms, the job is to nip inflation before it arises, and relax as the threat recedes.
 John Taylor, a former under secretary of the Treasury, once translated the factors he thought should guide the governors in setting the federal funds rate into an algebraic formula. To his surprise, the formula turned out to be predictive both for the Fed and for central banks overseas. William Poole, president of the St. Louis Fed, affirmed this in a speech at the Cato Institute just before Bernanke was nominated. While not suggesting that the Federal Open Market Committee saw itself as ''implementing an equation,'' Poole cited the Taylor Rule as evidence that ''the general contours of F.O.M.C. policy actions are broadly predictable.'' 
 Any process that a formula can come close to replicating is unlikely to be the fruit of a single bureaucrat's genius. And however adeptly the chairman has negotiated the economic cycles, the influence of broader, superseding trends is evident over time. In a backhanded way, Greenspan has acknowledged his limitations. Over the past two years, the Fed has raised the funds rate 11 times, yet long-term interest rates have failed to rise with them. Greenspan has called this a ''conundrum.''
 Last March, a Fed governor proposed that perhaps the explanation lay outside our borders. We know that Asia is selling us more goods than it is buying from us. Its surplus has been reinvested in America -- in the stock market during the 90's, more recently in bonds. A surplus of capital depresses the price of money -- thus, Asia's surplus liquidity has kept the lid on U.S. interest rates. This specific chain of events has been much debated, but it is indisputable that markets, including capital markets, are interconnected. Over the past several decades, Americans have gotten used to the notion that the prices of toys and televisions may be set overseas. Increasingly, the same may be true of our money. If so, the Fed chairman of the 21st century will share his influence not only with his peers in Washington but also with bankers around the world. The governor who proposed this theory, of course, was Ben Bernanke. A becomingly modest start.

HEADLINE: Echoes of 1986? Not in Bush's Tax Reform Panel

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
TWENTY years ago, President Ronald Reagan found himself politically weakened by large budget deficits, the Nicaraguan contra imbroglio and a Congress that was partly controlled by his Democratic opponents.
 Yet Mr. Reagan managed to push through a sweeping overhaul of the tax code that, at least for a few years, stood as a victory of bipartisan common sense over high-priced special interests.
That 1986 tax reform achieved two simple but powerful goals: it sharply reduced nominal tax rates and eliminated vast numbers of loopholes, special preferences and bizarre tax-avoidance schemes.
 Could President Bush achieve a comparable breakthrough? Not unless he changes his modus operandi in fundamental ways. 
 Mr. Bush took a first step toward tax overhaul on Tuesday, when his hand-picked advisory panel delivered two broad proposals for again purging the tax code of its complexity, corruption and cost to the economy. 
 But cleaning up the tax code creates winners and losers, and Mr. Bush has shown little appetite for confronting losers. For evidence, look no further than the corporate tax overhaul last year. That 700-page behemoth contained hundreds of special-interest tax breaks, including many that the Bush administration had openly opposed. But Mr. Bush, passively staying out of the fray, ultimately swallowed all of them. 
 One year ago, Mr. Bush proclaimed that tax overhaul would be one of his two big-vision goals for the second term, coming right after the overhaul of Social Security. But Tuesday, it was hard to avoid the sense that Mr. Bush's tax plan is headed toward the same place as his Social Security plan: nowhere.
 Mr. Bush himself said nothing about the long-awaited report. Treasury Secretary John W. Snow, who received the recommendations, said they amounted to ''a starting place.''
 On the tax issue, in contrast to the Social Security plan, Mr. Bush's biggest obstacle has little to do with uncompromising opposition by Democrats. Rather, Mr. Bush's effort is more likely to die as a result of constraints he put on his own tax panel and, by extension, on himself. Those constraints made it impossible for his panel to offer with a sweeping plan that would galvanize either the public or the Republican Party's true believers in a radical overhaul. At the same time, the panel's recommendations would provoke opposition from armies of special-interest groups with something to lose.
 Under Mr. Bush's explicit marching orders, the panel's proposals had to be ''revenue neutral'' and to assume that his tax cuts would be made permanent. He also ordered the panel to retain homeowners' tax breaks, one of the most expensive tax expenditures in the entire code, and to protect tax breaks for charities.
 Not surprisingly, the resulting plan was sober but uninspiring.
 The panel would eliminate the alternative minimum tax, or A.M.T., a parallel tax originally aimed at the very rich that is now set to engulf millions of middle-income families every year -- especially families with children. Eliminating that tax would be a major achievement, costing $1.2 trillion over the next decade, but it is an issue that has yet to affect most taxpayers and thus is unlikely to generate much excitement.
 The panel's main proposal would indeed simplify many aspects of the tax code -- for example, by consolidating a wide range of tax breaks for savings and retirement accounts. It would greatly benefit wealthy taxpayers by sharply reducing taxes on investment income, but it would also cut back on tax breaks that primarily benefit the rich. 
 However sensible those ideas may be, they fall far short of a radical overhaul. Neither of the proposals would have replaced today's system with a flat tax or a pure consumption tax, the goal of many Republican conservatives. More important, neither of the proposals would significantly lower existing tax rates -- a crucial attraction of the 1986 overhaul.
 Staunch conservatives who would like to replace the income tax entirely with a national sales tax were underwhelmed. ''Nibbling around the edges,'' complained Representative John Linder, a Georgia Republican.
 ''Small and quite complicated, and that's exactly what we're trying to get away from,'' said Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina. 
 At the same time, both proposals immediately provoked opposition from industry groups and their well-paid lobbyists. Mortgage lenders immediately lashed out at the panel's recommendation to trim back the huge tax deduction for interest payments on home mortgages. Life insurance companies wailed about provisions to tax the earnings on insurance policies. Big-business groups complained about taxing -- albeit very gingerly -- employer-paid health insurance.
 Such complaints are inevitable when tax breaks are up for debate. The problem is that special-interest pleaders have extraordinary political leverage if there isn't a big idea animating the overall project. 
 One of the panel's boldest ideas, for example, is to scale back the huge tax deduction on mortgage interest, and to use that money to offset the cost of losing the alternative minimum tax. The mortgage deduction has been sacrosanct ever since the income tax was created almost a century ago. It benefits tens of millions of families and is supposed to make homeownership more affordable and thus more widespread.
 But the panel offered a trenchant critique of the current deduction. It noted that the rate of homeownership in the United States is the same or lower than it is in Britain and Australia, which have no mortgage interest deduction. If there were no tax deduction for mortgage interest, house prices would almost certainly be lower, and the net cost of homeownership -- after a potentially distressing adjustment -- would be about the same.
 THE panel also noted that 70 percent of American tax filers received no benefit from the mortgage deduction in 2002, even though nearly 69 percent of families were homeowners. Fifty-five percent of the tax benefits went to the top 12 percent of taxpayers who earned more than $100,000 a year.
 Given that critique, the truly bold approach would have been to scrap the mortgage deduction altogether and free up tens of billions of dollars that could be used to lower overall tax rates.
 But the panel could not do that, because Mr. Bush had ordered it to protect incentives for homeownership. 
 As a result, the panel proposed two big changes. First, it suggested linking the ceiling for mortgage interest deductions to the average price of homes in each region of the country. In effect, deductions could not be taken for mortgages beyond $412,000, rather than $1.1 million under current law.
 Second, the panel proposed changing the tax deduction for mortgage interest to a tax credit. The advantage is that a tax credit is worth the same amount of money to all taxpayers, regardless of their income. A deduction against taxable income, by contrast, is worth far more to high-income people in the 35 percent tax bracket than to those in the 15 percent bracket.
 All of those ideas are thoughtful and defensible. But it is hard to imagine that they will prompt an outpouring of public support. That leaves the heavy lifting to political insiders and seasoned lobbyists -- precisely the people least likely to push for fairness and simplicity.

HEADLINE: The Bad Signs Are All Pointing Up

BYLINE: By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
WITH September and October -- historically the two worst months on the calendar for the stock market -- out of the way with minimal damage, one analyst is gearing up for a year-end rally. 
 ''After a 4 to 7 percent decline in the major averages from their midsummer highs, the market appears to be in a bottoming process,'' said Richard McCabe, technical research analyst at Merrill Lynch. ''This should eventually provide the foundation for a late 2005-early 2006 recovery during which those averages could moderately exceed, or at least challenge, their summer peaks.''
Just as any good drama needs the hero to overcome a formidable obstacle before there can be a happy ending, the market needed to fall last month to set up the chance for a strong 2005 finish, Mr. McCabe suggested in a note to Merrill clients.
 ''Since 1950, the month of October has registered a net loss, as measured by the S.& P. 500, on 22 occasions,'' he noted. ''However, 18 of those 22 down Octobers were followed by a net gain, averaging 5.9 percent, for the combined months of November and December.'' After a decline of 2.16 percent last month in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, he said, ''the prospects appear to be favorable for a year-end rally.''
 As a technical analyst, Mr. McCabe is less interested in corporate earnings and economic data than in patterns on stock charts and indicators of sentiment and momentum that have been shown to foretell moves in share prices. Those measures send the same message as the calendar, in his opinion.
 ''Sentiment indicators continue to show a healthy shift to caution or bearishness,'' he said. Lopsided negativity among investors often precedes a rally.
 Measures of internal market strength, such as the difference in the number of issues gaining and losing each day, and the trading volume in the two respective groups, also point to rising share prices, he said. He warned, though, that ''this does not rule out some further downside tests in coming weeks'' before the advance.

DATA WATCH -- The first test may come on Thursday, with the report on the nation's trade balance for September. Economists polled by Bloomberg News estimate a deficit of $61 billion, up from $59 billion in August. Later that day, the University of Michigan releases its preliminary assessment of consumer confidence for November. The Bloomberg prediction is for a reading of 76.7, up from an October figure of 74.2.
 The state of another deficit will also be announced on Thursday. The government is estimated to have spent $51.9 billion more in October than it took in, according to the Bloomberg poll. That would be a narrowing of the monthly fiscal deficit from $57.3 billion in September.

HEADLINE: And Remember, Vote Early and Often

BYLINE: By JOSH BENSON

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
FOR all the tens of millions of dollars that Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for governor, has spent on advertising, polling and hiring some of the nation's best political consultants, his fortunes on Tuesday could hinge on the whims of a moody mayor in Newark and a handful of prideful county chairmen.
 And for Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican candidate, who has pretty much been building toward this moment since his unsuccessful bid for the United States Senate in 2002, all of his painstaking efforts may be undone by the pique of a handful of well-organized conservatives.
In the end, the election may boil down to the last unanswered question in a race in which a significant number of voters remain undecided and even uncommitted: who will be able to get their supporters to the polls? ''Turnout is obviously the big variable here,'' said David Rebovich, managing director of the Rider Institute for New Jersey Politics. ''Both candidates are investing heavily to get their people to the polls, but neither of them has exactly run a perfect campaign. Who knows?'' 
 For their part, the campaigns are doing everything they can to avoid leaving things to chance. The Corzine team has, not surprisingly, lavished millions of dollars on county organizations, unions and urban churches in the hopes of reaping the benefits of a well-financed get-out-the-vote operation -- running phone banks, updating databases, knocking on doors and driving supporters to polling places. Party officials say that there are thousands of volunteers lined up for Election Day, many who will be paid $75 to $100. 
 And the Forrester campaign has made what aides have said will be an unprecedented level of investment in its effort to get voters to the polls. Those efforts will be aided by the recent pledge of nearly $600,000 from the Republican Governors Association specifically designated for voter-turnout operations.
 Although Mr. Corzine has consistently led in public polls throughout the campaign, the last week has been difficult because his embittered former wife, Joanne, joined others who have publicly accused him of essentially buying the support of New Jersey's Democratic leaders.
 Should the race tighten in the final days, and should many voters stay home because of their disenchantment with such a negative campaign, an effective turnout operation could prove to be a decisive edge.
 Both campaigns have their work cut out for them, though perhaps not in equal measure.
 Mr. Corzine -- who will be able to count on a fully functional party organization as well as on public employee unions, paid workers and what the state party promises will be thousands of volunteers -- would seem to have a natural advantage in this regard. 
 Unions, in particular, represent a unique advantage for the Democratic candidate. Despite the high political cost he has paid after the disclosure that he gave $470,000 to Carla Katz, a former companion, who heads the state's biggest public union, Mr. Corzine will benefit from his close relationship with labor. ''Their help is going to be enormous to Jon Corzine in terms of getting out the vote,'' said Leo Troy, a professor of economics at Rutgers University. 
 Mr. Corzine will also be able to count on the help of black church leaders upon whom he has lavished more than $2.5 million in contributions, helping to earn the gratitude and aid of influential figures like the Rev. Reginald Jackson, executive director of the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey. 
 And perhaps most important, Mr. Corzine will be looking for a return on his extensive investments of time and money in New Jersey's ascendant Democratic leaders.
 The question this time is whether they will be in the mood to cooperate -- particularly after the way Mr. Corzine signaled his independence by clashing with the Bergen County Democratic chairman over who should fill a vacant State Senate seat. The senator, after all, has run on the slogan ''unbought, unbossed,'' and has taken pains to dispel the notion that he is beholden to the party's power brokers. Now, in the aftermath of his wife's accusations, Mr. Corzine will be under even more pressure to demonstrate his political independence.
 So far, his efforts to distance himself from some of these bosses have not gone smoothly. 
 Take Sharpe James, the Newark mayor, who largely sat on his hands in recent weeks -- a crucial time when he might have been lining up important get-out-the-vote operations. Mr. Corzine recently aroused Mr. James's ire by seeming to embrace a political rival, Cory Booker, and by criticizing the construction of an ice hockey arena in Newark -- something that has been pressed vigorously by the mayor.
 In dramatic fashion, Mr. James declared last week that he would be back on board for the campaign. ''We're going to do it like we always do,'' he said. ''I plan to make up now for three months of inactivity by working 24 hours a day. I'm going to be going strong, going like a warrior.''
 Still, the flurry of activity raises the question of whether a few days' work can make up for months of inaction, and of how many other Democratic leaders have been holding back because of disagreements with the candidate.
 But the challenges of herding stray voters may be far greater for Mr. Forrester. In part, that is simply because he is a New Jersey Republican, meaning that his most intense support is found not in convenient and accessible clumps in the cities, but spread throughout the diffuse suburbs and rural parts of the state.
 He will be reaching out to those supporters with little help from a party organization that has been weakened in recent years as Democrats have come to dominate most of the state. 
 The Forrester campaign has consciously tried to make up for this wobbly infrastructure by investing heavily in its turnout operation, with many campaign workers earning $150 to transport voters to polling places.
 But those logistical plans may turn out to be irrelevant when compared with the more pressing prospect of a mutiny among conservatives, who have tended to be the best-organized component of the Republican Party and who would have to constitute the backbone of any Forrester victory.
 ''The guys who get up and go vote in an election like this are your solid hard-core activists, your base,'' said Steve Lonegan, the conservative mayor of Bogota, who ran against Mr. Forrester for the Republican nomination. ''These are people who go out at night putting up signs in the rain, work in front of shopping malls, knock on doors. I don't see them being energized for Doug. He certainly hasn't got his troops together.'' 
 The assessment was similarly grim, and the uncertainty as great, among some anti-abortion groups, who in recent years have been an important source of organizational support for Republican candidates but who have objected to Mr. Forrester's emphasis on his positions in favor of abortion rights since the primary. 
 ''There are an awful lot of people who are going to stay home or just write in a pro-life candidate,'' said Marie Tasy, legislative director of New Jersey Right to Life. ''We're still trying to get people out to support our candidates in Assembly races. But now it's tough to know what's going to happen.''

SECTION: Section 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front; Routine Changes, or 'Bait and Switch'?; Pg. 41

LENGTH: 1787 words

HEADLINE: Fewer Jobs and More Condos, Ratner's Opponents Complain

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

 BODY:
When the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn was unveiled in 2003, pamphlets given out at a news conference said it would feature ''iconic'' new buildings while balancing ''the needs of the existing communities and those of the people who would live, work in or visit the new complex.''
 It would provide 10,000 office jobs and more than 4,000 units of rental housing, half of it set aside for low- and middle-income families. Its centerpiece would be a Frank Gehry-designed arena for the Nets basketball team, topped by a ''lushly landscaped'' public park with ''outstanding panoramic vistas facing Manhattan.''
Most of those features are still recognizable in the project's most recent iteration, described in planning documents released in September and in the latest designs from the developer, Forest City Ratner Companies. 
 The Nets arena remains the centerpiece. The tallest building, dubbed Miss Brooklyn, will bring Mr. Gehry's trademark titanium waves to Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues. The other towers -- some smaller than before, some larger -- still stand amid acres of green space carefully sculptured to welcome residents of the adjoining streets.
 In other respects, however, the Atlantic Yards envisioned today looks very different from the one unveiled nearly two years ago. The project's size has jumped by a million square feet, and its dollar cost by 40 percent, to $3.5 billion. Commercial space, once a substantial portion of the overall square footage, has dropped dramatically, replaced by thousands of for-sale apartments and a hotel.
 Nearly three-quarters of the office jobs originally projected are gone; the new apartments do not count as part of the so-called 50-50 agreement under which 2,250 apartments are to be rented below market rates, and the park on the arena's roof is to be accessible only to residents.
 ''Projects change, markets change,'' said Forest City Ratner's executive vice president for development, James P. Stuckey. ''When you do a project over a long period of time, it's very difficult -- unless you're Nostradamus -- to figure out what the market changes and land changes and all those things are going to be.''
 But critics of the project say some of the changes, particularly the reduction in office jobs and the addition of thousands of market-rate condominiums, make Atlantic Yards into a less sweet deal for Brooklyn residents. The Democratic mayoral candidate, Fernando Ferrer, recently attacked the project as ''the twin brother of Mike Bloomberg's West Side stadium boondoggle.''
 Some opponents go further, saying the developer lured politicians and community groups with grand promises and then backtracked after the spotlight had passed. 
 ''They were willing to say anything to get community support, and that is why it is dangerous for the community to accept promises from the outset,'' said the Rev. Clinton M. Miller, a member of the Downtown Brooklyn Leadership Coalition. That group began talks with the developer over jobs and housing in 2004 but has since come out against the project.
 Several factors have converged to raise the project's price tag, including increasing construction costs, the above-market prices the developer has paid to buy out residents who live on the project's footprint, the extra $50 million the developer offered for rights to build over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority rail yard, and the cost of renovating the yard itself.
 Officials of Forest City Ratner said they eventually realized that they would have to reduce the amount of commercial space, to accommodate condominium units that would help pay for the project, including the below-market rental housing.
 But large real estate projects are subject to ''the butterfly effect'': Change one thing, and another changes.
 Because estimates of office jobs were based on the project's commercial square footage, less commercial space meant fewer office jobs. The earlier estimates were also based on a ratio of one job per 200 square feet of space, but the Empire State Development Corporation, which released the September planning documents, uses a less generous ratio of one job per 250 square feet of space, amplifying the reduction.
 The move to include more housing also increased the total square footage of the project. Because the ceilings of residential units are several feet lower than those of commercial units, however, it did not require more floors in each building. Indeed, the project will have one building less than originally planned, lowering its overall density somewhat.
 Critics said, though, that even the reduced job estimates were overstated, because they do not account for likely vacancy rates or for jobs lost when businesses currently occupying the site are forced out. Based on those factors, they said, the net gain from the project would be fewer than 1,000 new office jobs.
 Officials of Forest City Ratner -- the development partner in building a new Midtown headquarters for The New York Times Company -- gave several reasons for the switch to a private park. One was that as the buildings rimming the arena were re-mapped to house more residential units, there were fewer public access points for the roof of the arena. Another was that the city building code would have treated the park as a public assembly area, requiring cumbersome safety features. Finally, Mr. Stuckey said, discussions with planning experts revealed that ''generally, open space up in the air doesn't work -- people don't use it.''
 While the new plan closes the park to the public, he said, it adds more park acreage to the overall project.
 ''We took what was on the roof and put it on the ground where people can use it,'' he said.
 It may be the changes to the projections of new housing that have provoked the sharpest outcry.
 ''The problem is, Bertha Lewis and Mayor Bloomberg and Ratner are out there calling it a 50-50 plan, not a 50-50 plan just for rentals,'' said Daniel Goldstein, the spokesman for Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn. ''It's a bait and switch. What they announced as a revolutionary housing deal is not.'' Ms. Lewis, executive director of the advocacy group Acorn, signed the housing agreement last spring with Bruce Ratner, president and chief executive officer of Forest City Ratner and principal owner of the New Jersey Nets.
 The 50-50 deal and the more generous job numbers were frequently cited by politicians and others supporting the project, and favoring Mr. Ratner's bid to buy air rights over the rail yards for tens of millions of dollars less than their appraised worth.
 In letters dated last June and July -- weeks after Mr. Stuckey outlined the potential conversion to more residential units at a May hearing -- more than two dozen union leaders and elected officials expressed their support for Mr. Ratner's bid. Many of them cited the developer's earlier promise of 10,000 permanent jobs in the project's commercial portion and the so-called 50-50 housing deal with Acorn.
 ''The more than 10,000 jobs that will be created at Atlantic Yards will be a historic achievement for the future of Brooklyn's economy,'' read a letter from the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz. Similar letters came from Senator Charles E. Schumer, Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum and several members of the City Council.
 In an interview, Mr. Stuckey, the executive of Forest City Ratner, suggested that Forest City Ratner was paying a price for being forthcoming about its plans. He noted that the developer had met with dozens of community groups, had appeared at two Council hearings though it had no legal obligation to do so, and had publicly released pages and pages of documents before it would have been required to.
 ''What's interesting is that we've been out talking to people for two years. And this week, the approval process began,'' he said in an interview in October. ''Here we are opening ourselves up -- tremendous transparency, for two years. Yet the criticism is, 'Wait a second, they didn't tell us something about the evolution of their planning process before the public process began'? Just think about what that means.''
 ''It's Orwellian, almost,'' Mr. Stuckey added.
 The agreement signed last May between Mr. Ratner and Ms. Lewis applied only to the 4,500 rental units envisioned in the original plan. But it included a provision that if the developer added more residential units, the firm would develop 600 to 1,000 moderately priced for-sale units on or near the project site, in effect offering something close to a 50-50 ratio for all the housing associated with the project.
 At the time, officials of Forest City Ratner said they were already contemplating adding 1,500 condominium units, in part because community leaders had pushed Mr. Ratner to include more housing in the project. That would have given the project 6,000 units of housing. But during a City Council presentation in May, Mr. Stuckey said the developer was contemplating adding an extra 1,300 for-sale units, bringing the total to 7,300 units. 
 Those additions were specified in the September planning document, cementing the transformation of Atlantic Yards into essentially a large residential development with an arena and a relatively small amount of office and retail space attached to it.
 Forest City Ratner officials said that they had remained faithful to the Acorn agreement, which did not require that half of the new for-sale units be priced affordably. But if the developer chooses to build the maximum of 1,000 moderately priced for-sale units described in the Acorn agreement and builds them off-site, then the total number of for-sale and rental units associated with the project would reach 8,300, of which 3,250 would be priced below market rates -- about 40 percent.
 Much of the city's moderately priced housing is built through an arrangement called the 80-20 Program, under which city and state agencies subsidize construction projects by providing developers with tax-exempt bonds . In exchange, the developers set aside 20 percent of the apartment units for tenants who earn 50 percent or less of the area's median income.
 Ms. Lewis said that Acorn remained a strong supporter of the project and of the agreement with Forest City Ratner. But she said she was negotiating with the company, and with the government agencies that help subsidize housing, to help make a greater proportion of the for-sale apartments available below market prices.
 ''We know that when we get through this thing, half of all the housing is going to be affordable -- half of the rental, half of everything else,'' she said. ''We haven't gotten down to the last part of this. But our whole principle is 50-50.''

HEADLINE: Taking a Closer Look At the Two Candidates

BYLINE: By DAMIEN CAVE

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY takes its politics salty, overheated and occasionally laced with razor blades. 
 This year's governor's race -- pitting a Republican businessman, Douglas R. Forrester, against the Democratic hopeful, United States Senator Jon S. Corzine -- has been no different. The two candidates have poured at least $30 million of their own money into advertisements and tactics that turned nasty well before the leaves changed colors.
Most of the smearing, as nearly anyone who watches television can attest, has involved two issues: personal integrity and the state's property taxes, the highest per person in the nation. The advertisements for Mr. Forrester have sought to portray Senator Corzine as a friend of higher taxes, government waste and discredited Democrats, including former Gov. James E. McGreevey and former Senator Robert Torricelli, who both left office under a cloud of accusations involving corruption and cronyism. 
 Senator Corzine, in turn, has run ads claiming that Mr. Forrester and his pharmacy benefits company profited off the backs of ''working families and seniors.'' He has also attacked Mr. Forrester for aligning with allegedly right-wing tax organizations, and for failing to come up with a fiscal plan that would relieve the weight of taxes on homeowners and keep the state solvent. 
 In short, much of the campaign has been about positioning -- whether Mr. Forrester leans toward the same right wing of the Republican Party as President Bush, and whether Senator Corzine is cut from the same muddied cloth as the state Democrats who have been enmeshed in scandal. 
 Keeping track of the issues amid all of this has been as difficult as maneuvering through the Meadowlands parking lot in search of an exit. And the candidates' relentless focus on property taxes and corruption has yielded little insight into their specific proposals, frequently devolving into simplified slogans and semi-solutions. 
 But distinctions can be made with just days before Election Day. A close look at each candidate's record, combined with public statements, policy papers and interviews over the course of the campaign, will show a handful of areas where the candidates diverge. 

Property Taxes
A 30% Cut Over 3 Years, Or 10% Back Each of the Next 4
 New Jersey's property taxes are the highest in the country. While the average tax bill nationwide was $971 a person in 2002, according to the Tax Foundation, a nonprofit research group, here in New Jersey the average was $1,872. Connecticut, at $1,733, came in second and New York ranked fourth. 
 Mr. Forrester and Senator Corzine have talked incessantly about the issue for months, prompted by opinion polls showing it is the primary concern among voters. And in the handful of candidate debates, each has fought to undercut the other's proposal for lifting the tax burden. 
 Yet beneath the bluster, their plans sound remarkably similar. Mr. Forrester has labeled his initiative ''30 in 3'' because it would cut taxes by 30 percent in three years. For Senator Corzine, it is ''40 in 4'' -- a proposed 10 percent tax refund for each of the next four years in what amounts to an extension of the state's current rebate program.
 The cost of each proposal is the crux of where the plans diverge.
 Senator Corzine has estimated that his plan would cost about $7.67 billion, while Mr. Forrester has said that his plan would probably cost $1.4 billion in the first year, $2.1 billion in the second year and $3.2 billion in the third year, for a total of $6.7 billion. 
 Critics of Mr. Forrester's plan say that he is underestimating its cost; they put the price tag at $15.4 billion over four years. 
 Both candidates said that they would pay for their plans largely by streamlining parts of the state budget, including the state's prescription drug buying plans and other purchasing operations. But critics of both plans have questioned whether cuts and consolidation would be enough to pay for either plan. Moreover, they say that the proposals offer only temporary relief and sidestep the more important issue of structural reform. 
 New Jersey's high property taxes are, after all, largely a function of expensive local services combined with limitations on how money can be raised to pay for them. In at least 33 states, municipalities can raise money through sales taxes or other means. This is not legal in New Jersey, and neither Mr. Forrester nor Senator Corzine address the issue of how to help local governments pay the cost of running municipal services over the long term.
 As is the case in Congress, there are no plans for raising taxes -- just cutting them.

Corruption
Two Roles for Watchdogs And Who Watches Them
 In a state that has spawned more than 75 corruption indictments in the past four years, where Governor McGreevey resigned in disgrace amid a sex scandal, it should come as no surprise that the governor's race has often focused on a single thorny question: What can be done to clean house? 
 The answer is complicated, and each candidate has offered a laundry list of potential catalysts for change. 
 Both plans start with a constitutional amendment that would give the state an elected fiscal watchdog who would be charged with investigating corruption and auditing government agencies. Senator Corzine's official, a comptroller, would refer cases to the attorney general and would be elected every four years to make the office accountable to voters. 
 Mr. Forrester's anti-corruption crusader, called an auditor general, would have the power to file criminal charges on his or her own. The auditor would be restricted to a single six-year term -- to keep the office from being politicized, Mr. Forrester said -- and would be forced to wait two years before running for another position.
 The candidates also disagree on New Jersey's practice of dual office-holding, which allows a mayor, for example, to also serve as a state senator or member of the assembly. Mr. Forrester said he would ban state legislators from holding other elected offices. But Senator Corzine said that because serving in the Legislature is only a part-time job --and the most qualified person might already hold an elected position -- dual office-holding should be allowed. 
 The two candidates seem to merge on plans for ending pay-to-play -- the practice in which government contractors make political donations. In May, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey signed a law prohibiting the awarding of state contracts to individuals or businesses that contribute to a candidate for governor or the Legislature, or to a political action committee. Mr. Forrester and Senator Corzine have both pledged to extend the ban to those who contribute to county and municipal elections. 
 They have also said that they would end the practice of ''wheeling,'' the transfer of money between political organizations, giving county power brokers the ability to spread their influence throughout the state. And they would like to ban pension padding -- in which state officials are promoted to higher-paying jobs not long before retirement, allowing their pensions to be based on the higher salaries. 
 And the two candidates have slightly different proposals aimed at closing the revolving door between government and business. Under a law passed last year, the governor and cabinet officers cannot lobby government until they have been out of office for at least a year. Senator Corzine wants to extend the one-year ban on lobbying to all senior staff members in the executive branch and those who serve on public boards and commissions. 
 Mr. Forrester would like to extend the ban for the governor, cabinet-level officers and senior staff members to three years. For people who serve on the state's independent commissions and boards, he has also proposed a three-year ban on obtaining business from companies under their jurisdiction. 
 In addition, Mr. Forrester's plan includes several provisions not mentioned in Senator Corzine's plan, including calls for tightening the state's nepotism law, expanding the statute of limitations to seven years for a handful of corruption crimes for which it now expires after five years, and a new rule that would ban all gift-taking by state officials. Lobbyists would not even be allowed to buy a lawmaker a cup of coffee. 

The Gasoline Tax
Corzine: A Hike Is Hard to Justify; Forrester: It Will Never Go Up
 New Jersey -- home to the most-traveled tangle of highways in the nation -- is facing what some experts have described as a ''transportation meltdown.'' By next year, the Transportation Trust Fund, the state's primary mechanism to repair bridges and roads, will essentially be out of cash for maintenance and construction. All of the fund's $805 million budget will have to be used to pay off loans that state lawmakers relied on for transportation projects in the 1990's. 
 Two years ago, a commission appointed by Governor McGreevey declared that the best way to solve the problem would be to double the gasoline tax, which is currently 14.5 cents per gallon, one of the lowest rates in the nation. Other outside experts have also supported an increase.
 But not the candidates. During the summer, Senator Corzine said that an increase in the gas tax should be ''one of the last things we look at.'' Then in September, after Hurricane Katrina battered the Gulf Coast and played havoc with the petroleum infrastructure, and gas prices rose to more than $3 a gallon, he said, ''it would be hard to justify at this point.'' Instead, he suggested selling or leasing the state's toll roads, or simply selling the land surrounding the rest stops. 
 Mr. Forrester has gone even further, vowing never to raise the gas tax if he is elected. He said he would revive the transportation fund with money already in the state's $28 billion budget.

Homeland Security
First a Cabinet-Level Czar, Then Zeroing In on Targets
 Mr. Codey had to intervene last month in a turf battle over homeland security between the attorney general's office, the state police and the office of counter-terrorism. The public rebuke came less than two years after the Newark headquarters of Prudential Securities was found to be a terrorist target -- and in response, Mr. Forrester and Senator Corzine both offered plans for a security overhaul. 
 At the heart of each proposal: a cabinet-level czar who would coordinate and oversee the warring agencies. Mr. Forrester's plan would create an office of homeland security within the attorney general's office, which would have the lead role in overseeing cases and investigations. Senator Corzine's proposed director of homeland security would report to the governor every day. A commission, modeled after the 9/11 Commission, would study the structure of homeland security jurisdiction and make recommendations for how the chain of command should be organized and how collaboration should be coordinated. 
 Each candidate has also offered a raft of other ideas for improving security. Among Mr. Corzine's more specific proposals are new rules requiring the state's chemical companies to follow mandatory safety protocols for workers, first responders and neighbors; and a ''Serve New Jersey'' program of incentives that would forgive up to $1,000 in loans or provide up to $1,000 in tax credits to college graduates who enter, for instance, law enforcement. 
 Mr. Forrester's plan would include a study of all potential terrorist targets, including the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant in Forked River, small airports and chemical complexes. The sites identified as high-risk would be subject to more extensive security plans. 
 Citing the recent use of videotape in London to apprehend terrorism suspects, Mr. Forrester said he also wanted to put security cameras in bus and train stations throughout the state. ''Cameras would be in public areas,'' his plan states, ''and would allow police to immediately identify suspicious behavior.''

Development
Critical of Fast-Track, But No Details for Change
 A measure signed by Mr. McGreevey, but suspended in July by Mr. Codey, would expedite the environmental permit process in areas that the state had deemed suitable for development. Supporters have said that the law, known as fast-track, would revitalize urban areas, while critics have called it the worst piece of environmental legislation in state history. 
 Mr. Forrester and Senator Corzine have generally sided with critics of the law and have called for its repeal. But neither candidate has given specifics on what would replace it, instead calling for more study while making recommendations around the edges. 
 Mr. Forrester, for example, has said that the time period for development approval -- 45 days, according to the law -- may need to be changed. Senator Corzine has said that developers in urban areas should have expedited development while more rural projects should be subject to additional scrutiny and review. 
 Senator Corzine's position is also complicated by the fact that one of the law's architects, Susan Bass Levin, a former commissioner of the State Department of Community Affairs, is one of his leading campaign advisors. Senator Corzine's campaign maintains that this would have no effect on his determination to craft a new and improved law governing development. 

Education
'Turnaround Specialists' And Curriculum Changes
 When the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation, the three-year-old state agency charged with building new schools in poor neighborhoods, abruptly announced this year that it could pay for only half its proposed projects, residents of Newark, Irvington, Gloucester City, Passaic and several other municipalities ended up with empty lots, not schools. 
 Even worse, the mess might have been avoided: a handful of investigations later found that the agency wasted millions of dollars on exorbitant bonuses, excessive fees and costly design errors. 
 Both candidates have outlined strategies to put school construction back on track, and improve education as a whole. There are some obvious similarities. Mr. Forrester and Senator Corzine, for example, support a statewide bond referendum to pay for the completion of the 200 projects that the agency cancelled as a result of the shortfall. 
 Their plans for overhauling the agency's management, as laid out on their campaign Web sites and in speeches, are slightly different. 
 Mr. Forrester's proposal is more specific, stating that if elected, he would abolish the Schools Construction Corporation ''and assign the unfinished task of school construction to the Economic Development Authority with an advisory board of parents and educators that monitors and guides its work.''
 Senator Corzine's plan says that he would simply ''put a management and governance structure in place to ensure every dollar to construct our schools is spent responsibly and directed to our most urgent priorities.'' He does not explain what that structure may look like. 
 The two candidates have also proposed various ways to improve struggling schools. Mr. Forrester, following a program started by Gov. Mark Warner of Virginia, has said that he will try to help urban schools by recruiting and training principals to be ''turnaround specialists.'' Those who implement successful plans, he said, will be rewarded financially.
 Senator Corzine has focused more on curriculum changes. In a detailed speech on education in September at The College of New Jersey in Ewing, he said he would bolster early childhood education by dedicating nearly $24.5 million a year for full-day kindergarten, pre-kindergarten and after-school programs in districts where these programs are not already widely available. 
 ''My goal is that full-day kindergarten will be available to every child in the state by 2009,'' he said.
 Senator Corzine also said that he wanted schools to offer ''pre-engineering'' math classes in addition to more classes in Chinese, Arabic and other languages that will be important for students seeking jobs in an international economy. Mr. Forrester, in turn, has called for more mentoring programs and a closer relationship between high schools and community colleges.

HEADLINE: Signing Up Saddam's Soldiers

 BODY:
It is late in the day, but Iraq's ruling coalition of Shiite and Kurdish parties, and their American patrons, are finally showing some realism. The latest sign was last week's plea to mostly Sunni Arab junior officers of Saddam Hussein's disbanded military to enlist in Iraq's new national army. It was a historically stunning move, but one the Baghdad government had to make if there is to be any hope of making the Iraqi Army strong enough to break its dependency on the American forces. 
 It could not have been easy for the Shiite and Kurdish politicians, whose communities suffered terribly at the hands of Mr. Hussein and the army, which carried out many of his cruel and murderous policies. But the rash 2003 decision by the American occupation administrator, Paul Bremer, to disband the entire Iraqi Army was one of the worst of Washington's many postinvasion blunders. It made creating a new national military much harder, and broke the American promise that soldiers who did not fight the invading forces would be taken care of. It supplied vast cadres of armed, aggrieved and unemployed ex-soldiers to the developing Sunni-based insurgency, and undermined the legitimacy of the emerging Iraqi authorities by leaving them completely dependent on large numbers of American troops.
With the country so divided and the insurgency so powerful and entrenched, it will be extremely hard to make sure that former officers who have gone over to the insurgents do not infiltrate the new army. But it still makes good sense to try to undo as much of Mr. Bremer's disastrous decision as possible, as one element in a broader effort to reintegrate the deeply estranged Sunni Arab community into the nation's military, political and professional life. 
 Another costly legacy of the occupation was spelled out last week by the United States special inspector general for Iraq reconstruction. In a report to Congress, he showed how poor project coordination and monitoring, contracting abuses and astronomical security costs had allowed a substantial part of the $30 billion spent on American-financed reconstruction programs to dribble away without producing visible improvements in Iraqi life. These failures are inexcusable, but the truth is, no broad-gauge reconstruction can happen without significant gains in security, accompanied by progress on social and political issues.
 Re-enlisting former midlevel and lower-level Sunni army officers is a good place to start. But national reconciliation only stands a chance if it offers full professional and economic opportunities, including government service, to the skilled and educated Sunni doctors, lawyers and teachers, whose bitterness and economic hardship help fuel the insurgency. They should not be subjected to discrimination for having risen through the lower ranks of the former Baath Party, which used to be required for professional survival and advancement.
 We can only hope that the encouraging shift that produced last week's plea to ex-soldiers runs deep enough and lasts long enough to divert Iraq from imminent civil war toward constructive, democratic nation-building. With sufficient wisdom and a lot of good luck, it is not necessarily too late for Iraqis to salvage something positive from their long ordeal of dictatorship, war, invasion and occupation.
