HEADLINE: Hemisphere Meeting Ends Without Trade Consensus 

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER and ELISABETH BUMILLER

DATELINE: BRAS?LIA, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
A two-day summit meeting of leaders of 34 Western Hemisphere nations in Argentina, attended by President Bush, broke up Saturday without a clear agreement on when and how to resume stalled talks aimed at achieving a hemispherewide free trade agreement. 
 Mr. Bush had hoped to persuade his counterparts from Latin America and the Caribbean to deliver a resounding endorsement of the plan, the Free Trade Area of the Americas. But suspicions of American intentions prevailed in the end, and by late Saturday no final communiqu? had been issued. 
The White House, smarting from the failure of the talks, sought to play down the importance of an agreement.
 ''There's nothing in stone that says every time leaders get together you have to have a summit communiqu?,'' Stephen J. Hadley, the national security adviser, told reporters aboard Air Force One en route from Mar del Plata, Argentina, to Bras?lia. Earlier, he said people should not overemphasize the whole issue of the declaration. 
 The deadlock forced the cancellation of a final lunch for the leaders, as they sought to hammer out their differences. When the group took a 15-minute break, with the talks already three hours past their scheduled end, Mr. Bush left for his flight to Bras?lia. 
 White House officials said he had left to keep to his original timetable, which called for him to meet there on Sunday with the Brazilian president, Luiz In?cio Lula da Silva.
 Other leaders, including Mr. da Silva, began departing as well, eventually leaving the talks in the hands of lower-level officials. ''Reaching a consensus in a body of this size is sometimes a difficult task,'' a senior administration official said after the president had departed. ''We'd like to see the continuation of the free trade talks, and 29 countries have indicated their support for moving ahead.'' 
 American presidents of each party have long pushed for a hemispheric free trade zone. Ronald Reagan talked of a single market extending from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego; Bill Clinton formally broached the idea at the First Summit of the Americas in Miami in 1994.
 A Free Trade Area of the Americas would be larger than the European Union, though without its free flow of labor and political integration. Benefits for the United States as the dominant economic power in the hemisphere are obvious: with no more tariffs and other barriers that inhibit entry of American goods and services, American exports to the region would boom.
 But momentum has stalled, partly because the United States and Latin America are awaiting the outcome of trade talks at the Doha Round of the World Trade Organization, which will establish certain global rules any regional accord must respect. So the Bush administration has turned to smaller bilateral and regional agreements, like the Central American Free Trade Area, but came here hoping to get a commitment to resuming negotiations early next year.
 ''The reason why trade is so vital is because, particularly when addressing poverty, grants and loans pale in comparison to the amount of good that can be done as commerce develops at all levels of government, at all levels of society,'' Mr. Bush told a group of reporters from Latin American publications this week.
 But Latin America has never spoken with one voice on free trade. Many layers of doubt and dissent are on display here, and the situation may have been worsened by Washington's insistence on an agreement.
 On the left are those, led by Venezuela's fiery, populist president, Hugo Ch?vez, who oppose free trade in any form. Mr. Ch?vez calls the Free Trade Area of the Americas ''an annexationist plan'' that would stifle or destroy local industry, roll back social safety nets and labor protections and permanently extend American political domination of the region to the economic realm.
 ''We have to bury F.T.A.A.'' because it is the latest manifestation of ''an old project of the imperial eagle that from the beginning has wanted to sink its claws'' into Latin America, Mr. Ch?vez said Friday at a rally here of 25,000 people, who chanted anti-Bush and anti-Free Trade Area of the Americas slogans. 
 In contrast, Brazil and Argentina, the leaders of the Mercosur bloc, the third-largest trading group in the world, do not oppose the concept of free trade, only Washington's version. The Mercosur group, which includes Paraguay and Uruguay, was founded in 1991 to eliminate trade barriers among its members, but also aims to achieve political integration. It covers an area with a population of nearly 250 million and produces more than $1 trillion annually in goods and services. 
 As large exporters of foodstuffs, Mercosur wants the Bush administration to end billions in subsidies to American agriculture, in return for Latin American concessions on intellectual property rights, financial regulation and market access.
 ''We are here neither to bury F.T.A.A. nor to resuscitate it,'' but to see ''what are the advantages,'' Brazil's foreign minister, Celso Amorim, said. ''We have no prejudice against trade integration, but we don't want to put something on paper just because it looks nice.''
 Some other countries with dynamic economies that have free trade pacts with the United States, like Mexico and Chile, have been trying to ease their neighbors' worries, by emphasizing the benefits of liberalized trade for exports, investment and employment. On Friday, President Vicente Fox of Mexico criticized Argentina's president, N?stor Kirchner, saying he ''must do more to save this conference,'' and suggesting creation of a regional trade accord with 29 members instead of 34, leaving out Mercosur and Venezuela.
 ''Anyone who blocks an accord like this is certainly looking out for their own interests and not the interests of others,'' Mr. Fox said. 
 But President Ricardo Lagos of Chile said the United States needed to be more flexible. ''It is very difficult to promote free trade accords when you have this kind of problem, in which the asymmetry favors those who have more and not those who have less,'' he said.
 Brazil maintains that no hemispheric trade agreement can be meaningful without the participation of its fellow Mercosur partners.
 Argentina's stand is complicated by the resentment and mistrust from the economic collapse four years ago. Argentina contends that it was abandoned by the United States in its time of crisis, and that has colored Mr. Kirchner's dealings with the Bush administration.

HEADLINE: White House Tries to Keep Distance From Leak Case

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
In the hours before the Justice Department informed the White House in late September 2003 that it would investigate the leak of a covert C.I.A. officer's identity, Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary, gave reporters what turned out to be a rare glimpse into President Bush's knowledge of the case.
 Mr. Bush, he said, ''knows'' that Karl Rove, his senior adviser, had not been the source of the leak. Pressed on how Mr. Bush was certain, Mr. McClellan said he was ''not going to get into conversations that the president has with advisers,'' but made no effort to erase the impression that Mr. Rove had assured Mr. Bush that he had not been involved.
Since then, administration officials and Mr. Bush himself have carefully avoided disclosing anything about any involvement the president may have had in the events surrounding the disclosure of the officer's identity or anything about what his aides may have told them about their roles. Citing the continuing investigation and now the pending trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr., Vice President Dick Cheney's former chief of staff, they have declined to comment on almost any aspect of the case. 
 The issue now for the White House is how long it can go on deflecting the inquiries and trying to keep the focus away from Mr. Bush. 
 While there has been no suggestion that Mr. Bush did anything wrong, the portrait of the White House that was painted by the special counsel in the indictment of Mr. Libby was one in which a variety of senior officials, including Mr. Cheney, played some role in events that preceded the disclosure of the officer's identity.
 Mr. Bush was not mentioned in the indictment. But the fact that so many of his aides seem to have been involved in dealing with the issue that eventually led to the leak -- how to rebut or discredit Joseph C. Wilson IV, a former diplomat who had challenged the administration's handling of prewar intelligence -- leaves open the question of what the president knew. 
 The White House has also kept a tight lid on information about what Mr. Bush learned afterward about any involvement that Mr. Cheney, Mr. Libby, Mr. Rove and others may have had in the leak. 
 People involved in the case have confirmed that Mr. Rove told Mr. Bush and other White House colleagues in September 2003 that he had no involvement, but it is not known what, if anything, Mr. Rove has told Mr. Bush since testifying to the grand jury last year and this year that he had conversations with two reporters that touched on the identity of the officer, Valerie Wilson. What, if anything, Mr. Cheney and Mr. Libby may have told Mr. Bush remains a mystery.
 From a political perspective, the investigation now seems to be taking a toll on Mr. Bush. A Washington Post/ABC News poll released on Thursday found that only 40 percent of Americans see him as honest and trustworthy, down from 53 percent in May 2004 and 62 percent soon after he took office in 2001; 58 percent said they did not see him as honest and trustworthy, up from 45 percent last year and 32 percent in 2001.
 At the same time, Democrats are demanding that he live up to his earlier pledges to hold his administration to the highest ethical standards, ''not only what is legal but what is right, not just what the lawyers allow but what the public deserves,'' as Mr. Bush put it at the end of the 2000 presidential campaign. And Democrats are drawing renewed attention to an apparent change in Mr. Bush's standard for what would constitute a firing offense, to anyone who ''committed a crime,'' the threshold he used when he addressed the issue in July, from anyone who was ''involved in'' a leak of classified information, a definition Mr. McClellan used in 2003.
 More broadly, Democrats and their allies are trying to place the leak case at the heart of their argument that the administration has shown itself to be incompetent, dishonest and out of touch with middle-class Americans. ''Katrina. Iraq. Indictment. George Bush's presidency is in trouble, and he'll do anything to save it,'' said a new television commercial from People for the American Way, a liberal group opposing the nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. to the Supreme Court.
 ''We're at the very beginning stages of this, not at the end,'' said Representative Rahm Emanuel, Democrat of Illinois, referring to the political impact of the investigation.
 ''The president, politically at least, has an obligation to say something to the American people to get some clarity about what did they know and what did they say,'' he said. 
 But the Bush White House has always been good at what one close Republican ally refers to admiringly as ''making their own reality,'' meaning that the president and his top aides stick doggedly to their political script and agenda, refusing to be knocked off course. What Democrats consider stubbornness and detachment, Mr. Bush's admirers consider determination, and in this case that trait suggests the White House will be in no rush to acknowledge mistakes or to offer detailed explanations that might swamp the president's second-term plans.
 ''A White House that is aggressively on message is an unstoppable political tool,'' said Rich Galen, a Republican consultant. ''Just as the Clinton White House got itself back together in '95 and after impeachment, this White House will get itself together, too.''
 Whatever political problems the Libby indictment creates, he said, ''It's a long way from the Veep's office to the Oval. No one has ever hinted that President Bush was involved in this or was even aware of it. I really don't think the issue will have legs beyond the next couple of weeks.''
 The administration's supporters point out that Mr. Bush has repeatedly emphasized that the White House will cooperate fully with the special counsel, Patrick J. Fitzgerald. The administration raised no issues of executive privilege when it came to documents sought by investigators. Mr. Fitzgerald had given no indication that he was denied any information on the ground of national security. No officials are known to have taken the Fifth Amendment to avoid incriminating themselves.
 Therefore, allies of the White House said, it would be hard to make a case, legally or politically, that there was any organized effort to cover up what happened, despite Mr. Libby's indictment on charges of trying to do just that. And assuming that Mr. Fitzgerald does not indict Mr. Rove in the next few weeks, Mr. Bush has a natural firebreak available to him.
 He will be away from Washington for much of the rest of the month. After returning from a trip to South America, Mr. Bush will leave for a week in Asia and then will spend Thanksgiving at his ranch in Texas. 
 When he returns, allies of the White House said, he hopes to regain traction by moving smoothly ahead with Judge Alito's nomination, shifting the focus to the policies he intends to emphasize next year, including reduced government spending and an overhaul of the immigration and border control systems, and making a more effective case for why victory in Iraq is vital.
 ''I'm not sure he needs to say anything about the case until the investigation is over,'' Charlie Black, a Republican strategist, said, ''and then I'm not sure they need to do anything differently.'' 
 Mr. Black said the political repercussions from the case were ''a fairly temporary phenomenon'' that would fade in the next few weeks, giving way to the problems that had been presenting such a tremendous challenge to Mr. Bush before the leak case flared up this fall.
 ''The president's job approval long term is driven by Iraq and the economy much more than this leak stuff,'' he said. ''They know that.''

LENGTH: 2281 words

HEADLINE: For the City's Democrats, a Grim Future Could Last Long Beyond Tuesday

BYLINE: By PATRICK D. HEALY

 BODY:
As Democrats pursue an uphill battle to recapture City Hall on Tuesday, this year's mayoral campaign has already exposed the long-term fracturing of Democratic power in the city, from splinters in the black and Hispanic vote to defections in liberal bastions like the West Side.
 Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's popularity and his $66 million in campaign spending are two pressure points as the campaign winds into its final phase this weekend. Yet it is the permanent structural changes in New York politics -- such as term limits, campaign finance reforms and evolving demographics -- that are really shaking the once-dominant party and seem bound to hamper it for years to come, leading Democrats and political consultants say.
The Democrats have lost the last three mayoral elections, and if they lose Tuesday's it will be their longest stretch out of power since the consolidation of New York City in 1898. And the recent Republican successes have only empowered the mayor, whether in rooting out patronage in government or in pushing controversial priorities like the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn. As for the impact on voters, Democratic leaders say a lack of unity weakens party efforts to build more affordable housing, rein in apartment rents, allow gay marriage and battle for more school aid from Albany. 
 Democrats complain that fund-raising caps and term limits have deprived the Democratic challenger, Fernando Ferrer, of a political machine to confront the vast resources of the Bloomberg campaign. And he has not been able to spread his message in even traditional hotbeds of party loyalty -- a sign, some Democrats say, of wealthy candidates' triumphing over party-bred politicians who once defined power in New York.
 ''This is now a major problem for us, that the guy from the block who works hard for the party doesn't stand much chance against the guy who has $75 million,'' said Representative Charles B. Rangel, a party elder from Harlem who supports Mr. Ferrer. ''The old Democratic Party loyalty has faded; it's gone. And term limits are capping the futures of the best workers and minds in city politics.''
 While friends have described Mr. Ferrer as frustrated by the campaign, he projected a tireless optimism yesterday as he and Mr. Bloomberg stormed the city with a single goal: urging huge numbers of supporters to vote on Tuesday.
 Mr. Ferrer, who is about 30 points behind in most polls, visited all five boroughs yesterday to make a personal appeal to Democrats to return to the fold and ''get serious'' about improving low-cost housing, public schools and jobs.
 ''I'm not going to ask you to vote for me because I'm a Democrat, I'm going to ask you to vote for me because you're a Democrat,'' Mr. Ferrer said at a small rally in Harlem that was mostly attended by volunteers and staff members. He said he wanted Tuesday's vote to ''remind New York that Democratic values in City Hall are the things that made this city great.''
 For all the energy Mr. Ferrer showed yesterday, the weakening of the Democratic apparatus has been increasingly in plain sight. Mr. Ferrer has bragged this fall about unsurpassed party unity after the mayoral primary, yet many liberals, women, blacks and fervent Democrats appear poised to do their own thing: in this case, vote for Mr. Bloomberg in decisive numbers. The extent of Mr. Ferrer's lead among Hispanic voters -- he is of Puerto Rican descent -- is not clear, according to recent polls.
 ''A lot of people with Hispanic surnames aren't with Ferrer, and many Democratic notables have abandoned him or done little on his behalf,'' said Norman Adler, a longtime political consultant. ''One would think Freddy could win the West Side down to SoHo and TriBeCa and Stuy Town, but my guess is he'll lose all of it. What does that say about this as a Democratic city?''
 State Senator Liz Krueger, a Democrat who represents the East Side and who works on poverty issues, said that a split Hispanic vote on Tuesday, which she expects, would demonstrate that Hispanics are not a politically monolithic demographic, a base that Democrats can take for granted.
 ''Hispanics are pretty conservative,'' she said. ''Puerto Ricans, who have been here for generations and are citizens, often have different concerns than Dominicans or Colombians or Ecuadoreans.''
 Like other voters, many Hispanic and black voters also do not see Mr. Bloomberg as a Republican lackey to President Bush, no matter what Mr. Ferrer contends, political analysts say. Mr. Bloomberg has effectively driven ideological wedges among Democrats: They split sharply over embracing him as a socially liberal mayor who reduces crime, maintains services without raising taxes too much, and keeps corruption and special interests out of City Hall.
 A few other Republicans are following Mr. Bloomberg's playbook in their races for City Council this fall, giving more voters a choice in leadership and perhaps nicking the huge Democratic majority on the Council. 
 ''You could say the mayor is doing well because of his campaign spending, but voters care ultimately about priorities, and the fact is that his record is pretty liberal,'' said Jerry Skurnik, a political consultant who analyzes voter trends.
 But for some veterans of New York politics, the story of this campaign has been told, and retold and retold, by the seemingly unlimited campaign commercials paid for from Mr. Bloomberg's multibillion-dollar personal fortune. Mr. Ferrer has produced some edgy ads in the final week, but he is taking city matching funds that put limits on donations and is being outspent by eight to one.
 Mark Green, the Democratic candidate in 2001, argued that a Bloomberg landslide would show that blood is not always thicker than water. Ethnic pride in Mr. Ferrer and partisan kinship among Democrats ''seem to be submerged in a tidal wave of spending by Mayor Bloomberg,'' he said. 
 ''Some people are understandably swayed by ethnic feelings, but every African-American and Latino with a TV and radio has heard Bloomberg argue 100 times why he's good for them, even if he's white,'' Mr. Green said. ''They've heard maybe three times why Ferrer is good for them, even if he's a person of color.''
 He added, ''A lot of Democrats like myself were trained to think about voting blocs, but now we see there's no denying that money can trump a great deal.''
 The straying of black and Hispanic voters from the Democratic camp masks bigger challenges to party dominance in the city. The two main obstacles are term limits, which hamper the party's efforts to build an institutional leadership through incumbency, and campaign finance reform, which, with a generous system of matching funds, has encouraged novice politicians to confront the party's favored candidates.
 New Yorkers adopted term limits in 1993, but only in recent years has the law begun removing longtime Democratic fixtures of city government, forcing the Council speaker, for instance, out after two terms. As a result, there are fewer party power bases with personnel and money for Mr. Ferrer to tap, and fewer powerful incumbents who can rope in Bloomberg Democrats. Mr. Ferrer's best-organized backer, 1199/S.E.I.U., a union of health care workers, is contributing hundreds of volunteers and thousands of glossy pamphlets to his effort, but some Democrats question whether the aid will make a significant difference.
 ''Our power structures have really changed, and the mayor has his own power structure that is hard to beat: money,'' said H. Carl McCall, the Democratic nominee for governor in 2002.
 By remaining within the city's campaign finance system, candidates like Mr. Ferrer must accept caps on donations at $4,950 in return for the city's providing a six-to-one match of donations of $250 or less. Some Democrats championed this system, but the Ferrer camp and the state party are now chafing under its limits as they face a self-financed incumbent.
 ''A lot of Democrats want the Campaign Finance Board to rethink the rules once this election ends, because the playing field is unfair for average politicians facing millionaires and billionaires,'' said Bill Lynch, a Democratic strategist advising the Ferrer campaign.
 ''At the very least, the board should hold more debates for the mayoral candidates,'' he added. 
 Looking past Tuesday, some political analysts and elected Democrats say a Bloomberg landslide could embolden the mayor to perhaps try to wipe out partisan city elections, as he did earlier in his term, or to search for a Republican heir to run in 2009. By contrast, if Mr. Ferrer pulls out a victory, party strategists plan to take a close look at the ethnic and socioeconomic cross-sections that come together behind him, because the usual assumptions in the polls will have been proved wrong.
 Virtually no leading Democrat expects a Ferrer victory at this point, however, since Mr. Bloomberg appears to be ahead in traditionally Democratic enclaves.
 ''So many of the building blocks of the party are disappearing: ethnic voting blocs, dependably Democratic neighborhoods, the loyalty of unions,'' said John H. Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the City University of New York Graduate Center. ''If a Latino Democratic nominee and a white Republican are running neck and neck with Latino voters, what does that say about this city?''

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg

POLICY PROPOSALS
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has focused mostly on his record in office, but has also offered new or expanded proposals for more-affordable housing, education, economic development and counterterrorism strategy.

Education
Mr. Bloomberg plans to seek state legislative approval to double the number of charter schools in the city to 100 by 2009, and to give the mayor independent authority to create more such schools in the future. He would also add more alternative high schools to help students in danger of dropping out, and seek state money to expand preschool care for small children.

Public Safety
The mayor proposes making regional transportation authorities answerable to the New York Police Department the event of a terrorist attack on the transit system within the city, a move that would require the consent of the governors of New York and New Jersey. He would also establish gun courts in all five boroughs.

Housing
The city would increase the number of housing units reserved for low- and middle-income buyers to 165,000 over 10 years from the current goal 68,000 units over 5 years.

Economic Development
The city's marketing efforts aimed at attracting tourists would be expanded, and the mayor says he will ''work with labor, hotel management and the real estate industry'' to preserve the city's grand old hotels. He aims to rezone 4.5 million square feet of commercial space near J.F.K. Airport in Queens, create a 311 information service center for small businesses and expand development of the Harlem River waterfront.

PRINCIPAL ADVISERS

Kevin Sheekey
The campaign manager, he is Mr. Bloomberg's longtime political adviser and now is the architect and overseer of Mr. Bloomberg's election-year plan and sprawling campaign organization.

Patricia Harris
A top deputy and top confidante of Mr. Bloomberg's, she has the final word on his campaign budget and in recent weeks has moved to the campaign full time to help Mr. Sheekey oversee the campaign organization.

William T. Cunningham
A veteran strategist who oversees Mr. Bloomberg's campaign war room and provides key strategic advice on his campaign message and how he conveys it through the news media.

Edward Skyler
The mayor's Communications director, he devises and oversees the mayor's communications strategy and makes sure it is properly coordinated between the campaign and City Hall.

Doug Schoen and Bill Knapp
Mr. Schoen heads the campaign's polling unit and constructs its huge database of voter information, and Mr. Knapp oversees the huge advertising campaign.

HEADLINE: Bleeding Hearts of the World, Unite!

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
In a country dispirited by political mud wrestling, there was a spark of hope the other day: a conference in which liberals discussed international issues with conservative Christians -- and agreed!
 The conference, sponsored by Madeleine Albright on the left and Senator Sam Brownback on the right, underscored that we now have a tantalizing opportunity. If only left and right can hold their noses and work together, we can confront some of the scourges of our time -- sex trafficking, genocide, religious oppression, prison brutality -- on which there is surprising agreement about what needs to be done.
Democrats have mostly watched the arrival of evangelicals on the foreign policy scene the way the Romans regarded the approach of the Visigoths and Vandals, but that's a mistake. The growing engagement of conservative Christians on international issues is welcome because for the first time it has turned the American heartland into a constituency for foreign aid and humanitarian action. 
 A decade ago, the heartland was a force for isolation. That's why Tom DeLay said foreign aid meant ''putting Ghana over Grandma,'' and Jesse Helms referred to aid as ''money down a rat hole.''
 Now, in contrast, conservatives are leading the charge on some of these issues. Regular readers know that I'm no fan of this administration, but there's no arguing with facts. President Bush has almost tripled actual spending on overseas development assistance to $19 billion last year, compared with its trough under President Clinton of less than $7 billion in 1997, according to O.E.C.D. figures. (Mr. Bush hasn't given nearly as much as he's promised, but his broken promises still amount to far more than Mr. Clinton ever gave.)
 Pushed by conservative Christians, Mr. Bush is also doing more to fight both AIDS and sex trafficking than any of his predecessors did. Foreign governments are learning that the U.S. now takes the slavery of 13-year-old girls almost as seriously as the pirating of American movies, and that's a step forward.
 So that's the context in which Ms. Albright and Mr. Brownback (who call themselves ''the ultimate political odd couple'') held their conference, under the auspices of the Aspen Institute. There was a voyeuristic thrill of spying illicit love -- as when Mr. Brownback praised Hillary Clinton, who spoke on sex trafficking, for her ''outstanding job.''
 And cooperation can achieve more than just civility. Darfur is a perfect example of left-right cooperation that has saved thousands of lives, because the leaders in Congress against the genocide are Jon Corzine, one of the most liberal members, and Mr. Brownback, one of the most conservative.
 Of course, they have their work cut out for them: Congress just sent Darfur a ''drop dead'' message by cutting funds for African Union peacekeeping troops there. If Congressional leaders let that stand, they should just rename the bill the Genocide Enabling Act.
 What next? Ms. Albright and Mr. Brownback agreed on a tentative agenda by coming up with a list of ''the Top 5 worst places to wake up in the morning.''
 Those are Darfur, North Korea, Burma, Congo and northern Uganda. They're all neglected, brutal spots. Congo, for example, is the site of the most lethal conflict since World War II, with four million dead since 1998.
 Another area ripe for cooperation would be safe maternity abroad. For all the battles over abortion and condoms, both sides can agree that half a million women shouldn't be dying unnecessarily in childbirth each year around the world, when modest investments can save their lives.
 Domestically, the obvious issue is prisons, the nastiest places in America. A bipartisan coalition won a landmark law against prison rape in 2003, with evangelical leaders standing side by side with Ted Kennedy at the signing ceremony. The next step is the Second Chance Act, which aims to reduce recidivism by easing the adjustment from prisons into society. It stands a real chance of getting through this Congress.
 Obviously, there are differences. As I see it, conservatives have gravely undermined the effectiveness of their programs against AIDS with their squeamishness about condoms -- but there's still no doubt that the U.S. is doing far more about the disease now than it ever did under Mr. Clinton.
 Look, I think that Christian leaders on the right like Senator Brownback, Frank Wolf in the House and Chuck Colson are utterly wrong on many issues. I probably wouldn't vote for them for political office. But I admire them immensely for their humanitarian efforts, and I might vote for them for sainthood.
 Over the next year, Democrats and Republicans will devote millions of dollars to heap slime on each other. If they devote 1 percent as much energy to cooperating on a few of these issues, they'll make the world a much better place. Bleeding hearts of the world, unite!

HEADLINE: Hard Times, From the Gulf To the Coop To the Opry

Nov. 23

THE ICE HARVEST A pair of minor mobsters (John Cusack and Billy Bob Thornton) steal some money from their boss (Randy Quaid), but must then face the prospect of escaping an ice-bound Kansas city with their loot and Mr. Cusack's girlfriend (Connie Nielsen). Harold Ramis (''Groundhog Day'') directed from a script by Richard Russo and Robert Benton, based on a novel by Scott Phillips.

IN THE MIX The crooner Usher Raymond stars as a bodyguard who falls for the daughter of his employer, an old-fashioned mobster (Chazz Palminteri). Ron Underwood directs, bouncing back from the notorious ''Adventures of Pluto Nash.''

JUST FRIENDS A womanizing recording executive (Ryan Reynolds) considers reform when he runs into the woman he had a desperate, unrequited crush on in high school. With Amy Smart; directed by Roger Kumble.

THE LIBERTINE Johnny Depp, still looking for his Oscar, plays the dashing and decadent 2nd Earl of Rochester, a Restoration rogue who frolics with King Charles II (John Malkovich) and a young actress (Samantha Morton), among many others. Laurence Dunmore directs, from the play by Stephen Jeffreys.A related article is on Page 12.

RENT East Village youths sing their way through housing and health crises, in an adaptation of the musical directed by Chris Columbus (''Mrs. Doubtfire'') and starring Rosario Dawson, Taye Diggs and Idina Menzel. A related article is on Page 3.

SYRIANA Stephen Gaghan, who won an Oscar for his screenplay adaptation of ''Traffic,'' returns with another tale of international political intrigue, set in the Middle East, where several stories unfold and intertwine: a veteran C.I.A. officer (George Clooney) discovers the real nature of his work; an oil broker and his wife (Matt Damon and Amanda Peet) experience a tragedy; a corporate lawyer (Jeffrey Wright) agonizes over the moral compromises he must make in arranging a merger of two oil companies; a Pakistani teenager (Mazhar Munir) drifts toward Muslim fundamentalism. With Chris Cooper and Tim Blake Nelson.

39 POUNDS OF LOVE Dani Menkin's documentary tells of an Israeli man who has struggled with muscular dystrophy for three decades, so far successfully.

YOURS, MINE AND OURS The 1968 family comedy that starred Lucille Ball and Henry Fonda as a widow and widower who marry to create a brood of 20 children, here remade with Rene Russo and Dennis Quaid (and, according to the poster, a mere 18 children). Raja Gosnell of the ''Scooby-Doo'' films directs.

Nov. 25

DOWN TO THE BONE Vera Farmiga stars as a working-class mother of two with a secret addiction to cocaine; when she finally checks herself into rehab, she falls in love with a fellow recovering addict (Hugh Dillon). The writer and director, Debra Granik, won the Directors' Award at the 2004 Sundance Film Festival.

MRS. PALFREY AT THE CLAREMONT The American indie stalwart Dan Ireland (''The Whole Wide World'') went to England to shoot this adaptation of the novel by Elizabeth Taylor. Joan Plowright plays the title character, a lonely old woman who befriends a young writer (Rupert Friend). A related article is on Page 12.

Nov. 30

BOYS OF BARAKA A documentary, directed by Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, about a Baltimore high school teacher, Mavis Jackson, and her program that sends 20 boys each year to live in the bush country of Kenya.

December

Dec. 2

AEON FLUX The scantily clad professional assassin of the MTV animated series becomes firmly toned flesh in the form of Charlize Theron. Frances McDormand plays her employer, known only as the Handler. Karyn Kusama directed, in what is a big step up in budget terms from her independent debut feature, ''Girlfight.''

BE HERE TO LOVE ME A tribute to and documentary about the singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt, featuring appearances by Emmylou Harris, Kris Kristofferson and Willie Nelson. Margaret Brown directs.

FAR SIDE OF THE MOON Robert Lepage, Canada's leading theater director, takes another shot at filmmaking with a tale of two brothers (both played by Mr. Lepage) who continue to work out their childhood antagonism as adults.

FIRST DESCENT Kevin Harrison and Kemp Curley directed this blend of documentary and recreated incidents to tell the dramatic story of the rise of snowboarding. The snowboard stars Shaun White and Hannah Teter are featured.

A GOOD WOMAN At least the ninth version of Oscar Wilde's society drama ''Lady Windermere's Fan''; hope springs eternal, but even with Helen Hunt as the gallant Woman With a Past, Mrs. Erlynne, the director Mike Barker is going to have a hard time beating the classic Ernst Lubitsch version of 1925. With Scarlett Johansson and the hard-working Tom Wilkinson.

GOOSE! After the death of his mother, a little boy befriends a goose, convinced that the animal can talk. All is well until the school principal (Chevy Chase, whom some of you may remember as the Jon Stewart of 1975) decides to plump up the bird for Christmas dinner. It's a comedy. With James Purefoy, Tom Arnold and Joan Plowright; Nicholas Kendall directs.

THE KID & I Tom Arnold wrote and plays a role in this inspirational tale about a boy with cerebral palsy who dreams of starring in a big-budget action movie. With Eric Gores, Richard Edson, Joe Mantegna, Henry Winkler and Linda Hamilton; Penelope Spheeris (''The Decline of Western Civilization,'' Parts 1 through 3) is the director.

LITTLE MAN The filmmaker Nicole Conn (whose ''Claire of the Moon'' was a pioneering lesbian feature) documents the stress, strain and joy that result when she and her partner, Gwen Baba, adopt a seriously ill premature baby.

7 DAYS A young rock promoter (Eduardo Arroyuelo) turns to gambling to raise the money he needs to bring U2 to Mexico. Fernando Kalife directed.

TRANSAMERICA Felicity Huffman as Bree, a pre-op transsexual forced to take care of the son she never knew she had (Kevin Zegers) from a relationship she barely remembers from her life as a man. Is Oscar listening? Written and directed by Duncan Tucker.

Dec. 9

BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN A rodeo rider and a ranch hand fall in love in Ang Lee's western, based on a story by Annie Proulx. The lovers in question are Jake Gyllenhaal and Heath Ledger; with Michelle Williams, Anne Hathaway and Randy Quaid.A related article is on Page 12.

THE CHRONICLES OF NARNIA: THE LION, THE WITCH AND THE WARDROBE Walt Disney Pictures and Walden Media are hoping to start a ''Lord of the Rings''-like franchise with this first in a planned series of films based on the epic fantasy by C. S. Lewis. Andrew Adamson, who directed and wrote the screenplay with Ann Peacock, Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely, is best known for the computer-animated ''Shrek.'' Tilda Swinton plays the White Witch; Liam Neeson lends his voice to the Christlike lion, Aslan. A related article is on Page. 7.

EK AJNABEE The title of this Bollywood film translates as ''One Stranger'' and presumably refers to the character played by the Bollywood legend Amitabh Bachchan -- an aging gunman hired to protect an 8-year-old girl (played, no doubt, by a Mumbai Dakota Fanning) from a kidnapping plot. Apoorva Lakhia directs.

MAREBITO Shinya Tsukamoto, the Japanese cult director known for ''Tetsuo: The Iron Man,'' returns to acting as the protagonist of a new shocker by Takashi Shimizu (''The Grudge''). He plays a cameraman who prowls the streets of Tokyo, trying to capture authentic images of fear. And then he meets a mysterious young woman who leads him into an underground society of sadistic robots. And just in time for Christmas, too.

MEMOIRS OF A GEISHA The Arthur Golden novel has been in development for what seems like decades; it's now emerging under the direction of Rob Marshall, whose only previous theatrical film was the Oscar-winning ''Chicago.'' The story, of a poor girl from a fishing village who becomes the most celebrated geisha of the 20th century, may be Japanese in origin, but the cast is full of Chinese stars, including Ziyi Zhang as the central character and Gong Li and Michelle Yeoh as her rivals. The leading man Ken Watanabe, however, is indisputably Japanese. A related article is on Page 4.

MRS. HENDERSON PRESENTS The legend of Laura Henderson (Judi Dench), a wealthy society figure who founded the Windmill Theater, home of London's first all-nude review. With Christopher Guest, Bob Hoskins and Anna Brewster; the director is Stephen Frears.

THE WORLD'S FASTEST INDIAN Anthony Hopkins is the unlikely star of this inspirational sports film, in which he plays Burt Monro, a New Zealand motorcycle buff who set a land speed record in 1967. Roger Donaldson directed, returning to his native New Zealand after a frustrating Hollywood career.

Dec. 14

THE GRACE LEE PROJECT The Asian-American filmmaker Grace Lee combs the country for women who share her name, and learns about her ethnic identity while she's at it.KING KONG Peter Jackson's film is billed as a faithful remake of the Merian C. Cooper-Ernest B. Schoedsack classic, complete with computer-generated visions of New York City in the 1930's. Naomi Watts steps into the Fay Wray role, as the actress drafted by an adventure-loving filmmaker (Jack Black) to star in a semi-documentary being shot on remote, mysterious Skull Island. Adrien Brody is the writer on the project; Andy Serkis (a k a Gollum, in Mr. Jackson's ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy) is the ship's cook. With Thomas Kretschmann, Colin Hanks and Jamie Bell.

THE THREE BURIALS OF MELQUIADES ESTRADA An Oscar-qualifying run for Tommy Lee Jones's first feature film as a director; he also stars, as a Texas ranch foreman who takes it upon himself to avenge the killing of a Mexican friend. The script, by Guillermo Arriaga of ''21 Grams,'' won the writing award at Cannes this year (and Mr. Jones the acting prize).

Dec. 16

ELECTRIC SHADOWS The trials and tribulations of a pair of film lovers during the Cultural Revolution. Xiao Jiang, a Chinese woman making her first feature, is the director.

THE FAMILY STONE Everett Stone (Dermot Mulroney) brings his uptight fianc?e (Sarah Jessica Parker) home for Christmas, but the family matriarch (Diane Keaton) can't stand her. Thomas Bezucha (''Big Eden'') wrote and directed; the cast includes Claire Danes, Rachel McAdams, Craig T. Nelson and Luke Wilson. A related article is on Page 12.

THE PRODUCERS At least this one is a musical remake. Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick repeat their Broadway roles in Susan Stroman's adaptation of the Mel Brooks-Thomas Meehan stage show. Will Ferrell steps in for Kenneth Mars as the goose-stepping author of ''Springtime for Hitler.'' With Uma Thurman and Andrea Martin. A related article is on Page 4.

THE PROMISE Chen Kaige (''Farewell, My Concubine'') directs what is being billed as the most expensive production in Chinese film history. It's a romantic fantasy set in the ancient past, about a princess (Cecilia Cheung) who draws the love of a duke (Nicholas Tse).

WHEN THE SEA RISES Romance blossoms between a traveling performer (Yolande Moreau) and an outcast who makes giant puppets for parades (Wim Willaert). Ms. Moreau wrote and directed this French-Belgian production with Gilles Porte.

Dec. 21

CHEAPER BY THE DOZEN II The world will soon be divided into those who remember when Steve Martin was hip, and those who think he's the new Dean Jones. Here he is fronting a sequel to his successful family comedy of 2003, with the help of Bonnie Hunt, Piper Perabo and the multifaceted Hilary Duff. Adam Shankman directs.

FUN WITH DICK AND JANE Jim Carrey and T?a Leoni in a remake of the 1977 comedy about a Middle American couple who turn to armed robbery to make ends meet. Dean Parisot, who directed the delightful ''Galaxy Quest,'' is at the helm; with Alec Baldwin and Angie Harmon.

HOSTEL The director Eli Roth showed good instincts for genre form in his debut film, ''Cabin Fever''; he's back with another horror film, with Quentin Tarantino as one of the executive producers and a plot line about three American tourists who check into the wrong hotel somewhere in darkest Slovakia.

THE WHITE COUNTESS A blind, embittered former American diplomat (Ralph Fiennes) resolves to create the perfect dive bar in the Shanghai of the 1930's. Natasha Richardson plays the taxi dancer who helps him out. James Ivory directed from Kazuo Ishiguro's screenplay.

Dec. 23

Cach? (HIDDEN) Michael Haneke took the directing award at this year's Cannes Film Festival for this French-made thriller about a Parisian literary television host (Daniel Auteuil) who discovers his home is under surveillance for unknown but surely sinister reasons. With Juliette Binoche. A related article is on Page 16.

FREEDOMLAND Richard Price's novel, centered on a New Jersey woman (Julianne Moore) who may be lying when she claims a black carjacker has made off with her 4-year-old son. Samuel L. Jackson is the detective on the case; Edie Falco the local reporter who suspects something is wrong. Joe Roth directs.

THE MATADOR An assassin with emotional problems (Pierce Brosnan) meets a stressed-out businessman (Greg Kinnear) and his wife (Hope Davis) in a Mexico City bar. They have dinner together, with life-changing consequences. With Philip Baker Hall, Dylan Baker and Adam Scott. Richard Shepard directs.

MUNICH Eric Bana portrays a Mossad agent on the trail of the Palestinian terrorists who carried out the massacre at the 1972 Olympics. Steven Spielberg directs; with Daniel Craig, Geoffrey Rush and Mathieu Kassovitz.

THE RINGER Executive produced by the Farrelly brothers, Barry Blaustein's comedy stars Johnny Knoxville as a gambler who hopes to fix the Special Olympics by posing as a contestant. But when the other athletes discover his fraud, they befriend him and help him to train. With Brian Cox and Katherine Heigl.

Dec. 25

CASANOVA What's Oscar season without a new film by Lasse Hallstrom? The director of ''The Shipping News'' and ''Chocolat'' offers Heath Ledger as the legendary lover of the title. Sienna Miller is the elusive object of his obsession. With Jeremy Irons, Lena Olin and Oliver Platt. A related article is on Page 12.

HOODWINKED An animated retelling of ''Little Red Riding Hood,'' presumably packed with hip pop culture references and subtle flatulence jokes, just like most other recent animated retellings. Directed by Cory Edwards, Todd Edwards and Tony Leech; the voice talent includes Anne Hathaway, Glenn Close, Patrick Warburton and David Ogden Stiers.

THE NEW WORLD A peaceful community is invaded by violence-prone aliens in Terrence Malick's revisionist history of the early English settlements in Virginia. Colin Farrell is John Smith; Q'Orianka Kilcher is his Pocahontas. With Christopher Plummer, Wes Studi, Christian Bale and David Thewlis. A related article is on Page 8.

RUMOR HAS IT Jennifer Aniston as a bride-to-be who discovers that her mother (Shirley MacLaine) may have been the model for Mrs. Robinson in ''The Graduate.'' Mark Ruffalo plays her uncertain fianc?; Kevin Costner is the possible Benjamin figure. Rob Reiner directed, replacing the screenwriter, Ted Griffin, during the production. With Mena Suvari.

Dec. 28

MATCH POINT Woody Allen got his best reviews in years when this romantic comedy was shown in Cannes. Scarlett Johanssonplays the pivotal figure, a cold-hearted American seductress who is involved with both a former tennis pro (Jonathan Rhys-Meyers) and his best friend (Matthew Goode) in London. With Emily Mortimer, Penelope Wilton and Brian Cox. A related article is on Page 3.

MY NAME WAS SABINA SPIELREIN Elisabeth M?rton's documentary examines the life of Carl Jung's first analytic patient, who later became a psychiatrist herself.

January

Jan. 6

FATELESS The great Hungarian cinematographer Lajos Koltai (''Time Stands Still'') directs his first film, an adaptation of the Imre Kertesz novel about a 14-year-old Jewish boy (Marcell Nagy) who survives the Holocaust but must then learn to survive the liberation, when he returns to a Budapest that would prefer to forget.

GRANDMA'S BOY Alex (Allen Covert), a lovable loser and 35-year-old professional tester of video games, moves in with his grandmother (Doris Roberts) and her two elderly roommates. Hilarity ensues! Nick Goossen directed.IDLEWILD Two members of OutKast, Andr? Benjamin (a k a Andr? 3000) and Antwan Patton (Big Boi), star as a piano player and a nightclub singer in a musical set in the American South of the 1930's. Bryan Barber directed and wrote the script with Doug Stern.

RUNNING SCARED Paul Walker sports some facial hair as a big-city cop in trouble with the mob, his wife and a corrupt colleague (Chazz Palminteri). Wayne Kramer (''The Cooler'') directs.

WOLF CREEK A trio of attractive young tourists (Cassandra Magrath, Nathan Phillips, Kestie Morassi) backpacking through the Australian outback run into some ''Texas Chainsaw''-type trouble in this Aussie variant on the ever popular crazed-hayseed genre. Greg McLean directed.

Jan. 13

DATE MOVIE More genre parody from part of the team behind ''Scary Movie 3'' -- shouldn't they have called this one ''Chick Flick''? Alyson Hannigan plays the lonely urban romantic who falls for a handsome British cad (Adam Campbell) with a name that can't be printed in a family newspaper. Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer direct.

GLORY ROAD More sports-related inspiration from the Walt Disney organization. This one is based on the 1966 Texas Western basketball team that became the first to win the N.C.A.A. championship with an all-black lineup. Josh Lucas plays the coach who leads them from zeros to heroes; James Gartner directs.

LAST HOLIDAY A shy saleswoman (Queen Latifah) decides to carpe that diem and take the European vacation she's always dreamed of. Wayne Wang directed this remake of the 1950 Alec Guinness vehicle, which seems to have undergone some alterations.

Jan. 20

END OF THE SPEAR A group of five American missionaries are murdered by an Amazon tribe in 1956, in a true-life story directed by Jim Hanon and written by Mr. Hanon, Bill Ewing and Bart Gavigan.

LOOKING FOR COMEDY IN THE MUSLIM WORLD Albert Brooks wrote and directed this mockumentary, a form he helped create with the brilliant ''Real Life'' (1979). He plays himself, more or less -- a Hollywood comic who is tapped by the clueless United States government to find out what, if anything, makes Muslims laugh.

UNDERWORLD: EVOLUTION The epic battle of the vampires versus the werewolves, explored in ''Underworld'' (2003), continues in this sequel, still under the direction of Len Wiseman. Kate Beckinsale returns as the dashing vampire heroine; Scott Speedman is the half-werewolf who shares her quest.

WHY WE FIGHT Eugene Jarecki's documentary appropriates the title of Frank Capra's famous series of World War II propaganda films, but comes to a conclusion that differs from Capra's: we fight to keep the economy moving. The talking heads include John McCain, Gore Vidal and William Kristol.

Jan. 27

ANNAPOLIS An ambitious officer candidate (James Franco) learns to be a man from his commanding officer (Tyrese Gibson) in yet another inspiring tale from the Walt Disney organization. Justin Lin, in quite a stretch from his darkly comic 2002 ''Better Luck Tomorrow,'' is the director.

BIG MOMMA's HOUSE 2 The public demanded more of Martin Lawrence in fat-suit and drag, and Fox, ever compassionate, has responded with this sequel to Mr. Lawrence's thespian triumph of 2000. John Whitesell directed.

BUBBLE Made with nonprofessional actors in a small Ohio town, Steven Soderbergh's digitally shot murder mystery will make its debut simultaneously in theaters, on DVD and on HDNet. Good luck with that.

NANNY MCPHEE Universal goes looking for its children's franchise with this strangely familiar sounding story of a nanny with magical powers (Emma Thompson, who also wrote the screenplay) who steps in to straighten out the ill-behaved children of an English family. With Colin Firth, Derek Jacobi and Angela Lansbury.

TRISTAM SHANDY: A COCK AND BULL STORY From the prolific Michael Winterbottom, an adaptation of Laurence Sterne's premodernist novel about an 18th-century eccentric (Steve Coogan) whose attempt to tell his life story is constantly interrupted by apparently irrelevant distractions. In Mr. Winterbottom's version, it's the shooting of the film that starts and stops. With Rob Brydon, Gillian Anderson, Kelly Macdonald, Jeremy Northam and Shirley Henderson.

All dates are subject to change.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 6, 2005
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 7; Column 2; Book Review Desk; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 1372 words

HEADLINE: The Rich and the Rest

BYLINE: By Charles Peters. 
Charles Peters is the author of ''Five Days in Philadelphia: The Amazing 'We Want Willkie!' Convention of 1940 and How It Freed FDR to Save the Western World.''

 BODY:
RESTLESS GIANT
 The United States From Watergate
 to Bush v. Gore.
 By James T. Patterson.
 Illustrated. 448 pp. Oxford University Press. $35.
THIS is first-rate history by a first-rate historian. Unlike many of his brethren, James T. Patterson can write, and he understands the value of vivid detail, using ''Annie Hall,'' ''Norma Rae'' and ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' to help explain the women's movement. What's more, he can think, and he offers analysis and interpretation that is consistently sensible, if sometimes a trifle Panglossian.
 The events he describes make up the history -- social, economic and political -- of the United States during the final quarter of the 20th century, from Richard Nixon's departure from the White House and America's departure from Vietnam to the bitter partisanship of Bill Clinton's impeachment and Bush v. Gore. 
 In between, he recalls the Ford and Carter administrations and the Iranian hostage crisis, the rise of Ronald Reagan and the resurgence of American conservatism, Bush 1 and Iraq 1, and President Clinton's economic triumphs and missed opportunities. 
 These were the years the Republicans took over. They gained control of the judiciary. Reagan alone, Patterson notes, appointed ''nearly half of all judges'' on the federal courts. Five Republican justices of the United States Supreme Court awarded the presidency to a Republican in 2000. And the Republicans chipped away at Democratic majorities in Congress before taking control of both houses in 1994. 
 The conservative surge found new foot soldiers among the growing ranks of evangelical Christians, the great majority of whom leaned to the right. This tendency was intensified by the failure of liberals to try to reach out to the evangelicals. Patterson views these developments with equanimity, seeing a country still dominated by reasonable centrists as the new century began and citing the close 2000 election to illustrate his point. A worried liberal might argue that the rightward trend continued in 2004, as George W. Bush won by a clear majority.
 Nonetheless, one of the high points of Patterson's book is his account of how the Supreme Court handed the presidency to a candidate who had lost the popular vote by more than a half-million, using legal reasoning that conspicuously departed from the conservative judicial principles ordinarily favored by the five justices in the majority. Although Patterson makes clear that more Floridians intended to vote for Gore than for Bush, his keen sense of fairness, one of his great merits, leads him not only to a sympathetic recitation of Republican arguments but also to pointed criticism of Gore's attempts to cherry-pick the votes to be reviewed.
 Equally admirable is the account of the Reagan era. Patterson avoids both the automatic adulation of the right and the reflexive dismissiveness of the left. He recognizes Reagan's admirable refusal to follow the established foreign policy wisdom, which viewed the Soviet Union as a reality that must be accepted. Yet even as Reagan condemned the ''evil empire,'' he reached out to Mikhail Gorbachev to achieve the first nuclear disarmament agreement between the United States and the Soviets. This was the good side of Reagan that liberals resist conceding. His other side, the one conservatives refuse to acknowledge, is also captured by Patterson, who shows us a president too fond of tax cuts and big business and often alarmingly disconnected from what was happening in his own administration.
 Elsewhere, Patterson equals or comes very close to the high level he attains writing about Reagan. He made me sympathize for the first time with Gerald Ford's pardon of Nixon; he reminds us that if we must go to war, Bush 1's way is infinitely preferable to his son's; and he exposes the disgraceful widening gap between the rich and the rest of us. ''By 1998,'' he notes, ''the average income of the 13,000 wealthiest families in the United States was 300 times that of average families.''
 My main complaint about ''Restless Giant'' is that there is not enough of it. Patterson's previous work in the ''Oxford History of the United States'' series, ''Grand Expectations,'' covering the period from 1945 to 1974, weighed in at 829 pages, while the current volume, covering just four fewer years, has only 448. The result is that some important matters are either ignored or given too little attention.
 One example is the rise of the meritocracy and the accompanying obsession with test scores, school admission and the acquisition of badges of taste and intellect recognizable by other members of the educated elite. That group, largely composed of political liberals, has become more concerned with distinguishing itself from average Americans than with reaching out to them. This development is not unrelated to the fact that average Americans have been steadily deserting liberalism and the Democratic Party. 
 Another disappointment is Patterson's failure to explore what has gone wrong with journalism. He sees how a mixture of sex, violence and fame, as in the O. J. Simpson case, can mesmerize the news media. But he does not seem aware that too many reporters, yearning to be stars themselves, prefer to cover such stories. When one Big Story dominates the news, important problems are not faced because they are underreported or not reported at all. Consider, for instance, what went wrong at FEMA between 2001 and 2005 and how we didn't read about it until after Hurricane Katrina.
 The Big Story can also lead to absurdity, and this Patterson does understand. Recalling Monica Lewinsky's appearance on ''20/20'' with Barbara Walters, he writes: ''An estimated 70 million Americans watched. . . . No single network 'news' program had ever been seen by so many people. ABC demanded and received record payments . . . for commercials. And what commercials! These included Victoria's Secret lingerie, the Oral-B deluxe toothbrush and a promo for the movie 'Cleopatra' that included the voice-over: 'When she was 20, she seduced the most powerful leader in the world.' A Maytag ad boasted of its product, 'It actually has the power to remove stains.' '' 
 Like most historians (and reporters, for that matter), Patterson exhibits little understanding of practical politics. By joining those who scorn Clinton's use of the Lincoln Bedroom for political fund-raising, the author shows he never had to face the problem of trying to find clean money for a campaign. If he had, he would realize that giving a contributor a bed for the night is far preferable to giving him influence over official decisions.
 Patterson's tendency to see the glass as half full colors his treatment of the increase in partisanship. When he says there are enough ''moderates, independents and centrists'' to make the system work, he is not describing today's Washington. He is right to say the people are not as partisan as the politicians, but it is the politicians who make the laws and who determine what government does or doesn't do.
 PATTERSON captures one of the era's most deplorable trends, the increase in individual and group selfishness that has manifested itself in, among other things, huge executive salaries and irresponsible tax cuts. He also zeroes in on one cause of this trend that few others have perceived: the ''rights revolution,'' which brought laudable progress for blacks, women and the disabled, but as it spread to other individuals and groups often transformed itself into a sense of entitlement without accompanying obligation, of rights without duties. 
 The author seems almost fatalistic about this trend. When he observes that Americans are not given to sacrifice, he appears to forget there was a time when we all did our part. From 1940 until the escalation in Vietnam in the mid-60's, Americans of every class were willing to subject themselves to a military draft. That ended with Lyndon Johnson's unfair draft, but it proved Americans are capable of sacrifice for the good of the country -- and not just for a day or two.
 Still, despite its faults, ''Restless Giant'' is a splendid book that will come to be regarded as indispensable to everyone who cares about the history of this country.

HEADLINE: Dance Preservation Organization, in Financial Turmoil, Lays Off Most of Staff

BYLINE: By ERIKA KINETZ

 BODY:
Since it was founded in 1940, the Dance Notation Bureau has been at the forefront of dance preservation, and it has one of the most important collections of dance scores in the nation. But on Oct. 28, it laid off five of its six staff members, including its executive director, Ilene Fox.
 ''We ran out of money,'' said Lynne Weber, chairwoman of the board of the New York-based organization. ''We were not aware the financial situation was as bad as it was.'' 
Dance notation, using a system of symbols called Labanotation and functioning much like a music score, enables dances to be recreated accurately long after a choreographer has died. The bureau's library houses more than 700 scores for dances by choreographers from George Balanchine and Doris Humphrey to Bill T. Jones and Mark Morris. It also has other material that can help in reconstructing a work, including videotapes and films, musical scores, costume sketches, photographs and old programs.
 In addition to Western theatrical dance, the collection includes scores for social, historical and folk dances from around the world. It is thus an important resource for companies recreating works and for scholars of dance history. 
 For now, the library remains active and accessible. (Mei-Chen Lu, who oversees it, was the only employee to survive the cuts.) But the institution is on the ropes.
 Grant money it had been expecting failed to materialize. The fall membership drive met with lackluster results. And individual donations, which constitute about half of the $300,000 annual operating budget, are also down.
 The fiscal problems were aggravated by disorganization. Within the last few years, three board members and one employee have died, Ms. Weber said in an interview on Friday. In May, the bookkeeper stopped showing up for work. Ms. Fox, as executive director, spent the summer teaching in Taiwan, giving a presentation in Malaysia, attending a conference in London and working on a major grant application. A new bookkeeper was brought on board only in late September.
 ''I was doing three jobs,'' Ms. Fox said. ''I kept saying my title should be changed from executive director to chief juggler.''
 The September board meeting was canceled. Not until an executive committee meeting on Oct. 26 did the extent of the fiscal crisis become clear.
 ''We were spending more than we were taking in,'' Ms. Weber said. ''The executive committee realized we had to take drastic measures to make sure we survived.''
 Ms. Weber, Ms. Fox and Senta Driver, another board member, went directly to the office, on West 30th Street, and informed the staff that everyone except the librarian would be laid off two days later. The news came as a shock to employees.
 ''We didn't expect it at all,'' said Mira Kim, a notation associate responsible for digitizing handwritten scores. A donation has since come in that will make it possible for Ms. Kim to return to work today. ''I'm super-excited,'' she said by telephone on Friday, minutes after learning that she was no longer unemployed.
 For an organization with almost no staff and no money, the Dance Notation Bureau is still buzzing. Call the office, and someone will answer. On Friday, five people -- four of them volunteers -- turned up to work.
 ''It looks like we will be able to survive,'' Ms. Weber said. ''What we need to do is restructure.''
 Projects with outside financing will go forward. The bureau offers the only professional certification program for dance notation in the country. Classes for the two current students will continue, and this spring, the bureau's extension at Ohio State University will check the score for Mark Morris's ''All Fours,'' as planned, verifying the notation work that has already been done and mounting a staging based on it for Mr. Morris's review.
 The bureau is still waiting for a $42,000 grant that would allow it to create scores for two pieces, one by William Forsythe and one by Martha Graham. It is also hoping to get financing to continue developing LabanDancer, a software program that translates dance scores into animation.
 Calls of support have come in, but little money. ''They all want to send petitions,'' said Ms. Driver, the board member, who has been helping spearhead the restructuring. ''We haven't figured out to whom we might send them.''
 The bureau is still searching for long-term solutions. It is considering subletting part of its office space and trying to forge alliances with other institutions, but its immediate plan is to hope the grants come in and donations increase.
 ''Right now we're taking it day by day,'' said Ms. Weber, the chairwoman. ''Are we going to be smaller? The same size? What are we going to look like? We don't know.''
 Labanotated dance scores, which can take years to create, are more precise than video recordings, the most widely used method of preservation today. In videos, dancers may be blocked, depending on the angle of the camera. Moreover, different dancers perform the same choreography differently, and even the same dancer can perform the same role differently on different nights. So as a dance passes from generation to generation, the choreographer's intent can become muddied
 ''We take it absolutely for granted that we can continue to enjoy Bach or Beethoven,'' said Ms. Fox, the former executive director. ''Everyone has seen a work of Shakespeare at one time or another. Dance doesn't have that kind of legacy.''

HEADLINE: Native Eyes on a Land South of the Clouds

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
He was herding goats high up the creases of sacred Mount Kawagebo when the morning light seemed right, recalled Ananzhu, an ethnic Tibetan from an isolated village of southern China. So he took out his camera. The scene he captured that day, of an emerald lake beneath two conical, ice-capped peaks, was both stunning and layered with meanings. 
 Ananzhu (he has only one name) was carrying a camera provided by the United States-based Nature Conservancy as part of a Photovoice project. 
More than 250 people from 60 villages in northern Yunnan province, all from ethnic minorities, have been given a way to document, through their own eyes, their cultures and surroundings. 
 His alpine scene is one of some 45 photographs from the project now on display at the American Museum of Natural History in ''Voices From South of the Clouds'' (a reference to Yunnan, Chinese for ''south of the clouds''). The exhibition is in the small Akeley gallery, behind the African mammals, and runs until March 12. 
 Ananzhu was one of three village photographers the conservancy brought to New York last week for a cultural celebration. The pictures provide a record of endangered traditions and landscapes but the main goal, said Ann McBride Norton, a conservancy adviser in Asia who organized the project, is to give a voice to northern Yunnan's diverse peoples. 
 The region's myriad ethnic groups -- including many people who are illiterate and do not even speak Chinese -- are facing surges in tourism, road-building and investment. The conservancy is working with local officials to promote environmentally benign development, an idea with shallow roots in economically booming China. 
 With some of the last unspoiled remnants in all of China, Yunnan is not only ethnically but also biologically rich, a ''hot spot'' for plant species including 162 species of rhododendron that sprinkle the hillsides with pink flowers each spring. 
 Helping indigenous people to document themselves with photographs is a longtime technique of anthropologists. The Natural History museum was drawn to the Yunnan pictures because they capture the nexus between culture and environment, said Eleanor Sterling, co-curator of the show and director of the museum's center for biodiversity and conservation. And crucially, she said, ''the photos were spectacular.'' 
 In starting the project, Ms. Norton drew inspiration and advice from the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University, where the photographer Wendy Ewald has been a pioneer in the combined use of cameras and writing as a way to stimulate learning and community awareness in schools and elsewhere. 
 ''Photography is a pretty democratic art form,'' noted Katy Hyde, director of the Literacy Through Photography program at the Duke center.
 For the Yunnan project, the Eastman Kodak Company donated point-and-shoot cameras (a model that sells for $7 in China). In short training sessions, villagers were taught how to use them and, rather than being told what makes a good picture, they were shown multitudes of photographs and encouraged to discuss what they liked and why. 
 They are provided with one roll of film each month, along with the results of the previous month's effort. They are asked to provide background information on the pictures that is sometimes quite revealing. 
 In the case of his mountain scene, Ananzhu, 41, wrote that when he saw the same spot as a child, the lake was much smaller. ''The glacier is shrinking and the lake is growing, and we don't know why,'' he said in an interview. 
 When his picture was displayed in his home village of Yubeng, elders were prompted to tell children the sacred meaning of the pictured valley: the meeting place of the war gods of Mount Kawagebo. 
 Several of the fledgling photographers turned out to have a particularly good eye. Hong Zhengyong's image of a girl in distinctive ethnic dress slaughtering a chicken amid dazzling yellow fields, for example, is one of several in the exhibition with classic diagonals and symmetries. 
 Mr. Hong, 28, mainly photographed his father, one of the last great Yi shamans, performing healing rituals and animal sacrifices. ''I worry that the knowledge will be lost,'' he said in New York. He documented the rituals just in time: his father recently died. 
 Some of the pictures celebrate scenic splendors and participants, including Ananzhu, said they did not fully appreciate the beauty around them until they saw it in a photograph. 
 Others document hardships: children collecting firewood, or writing their homework on the side of a basket as they accompany their parents to farm plots. The caption to a picture of a Tibetan woman milking a yak in a blizzard says, ''Even in wintertime we have to go out to get milk.''
 After touring New York, the villagers said they were impressed but not overawed. The buildings are very tall, said Ananzhu. ''But even the tallest building,'' he noted, ''is not as high as our lowest mountain.''

HEADLINE: Oil Producers Are Urged To Invest in More Capacity

BYLINE: By JAD MOUAWAD

 BODY:
Oil prices will keep rising over the next two decades unless the oil-rich nations of the Middle East and North Africa substantially increase investments in their energy sectors, warns a new report to be released today by the organization that represents energy-consuming nations. 
 The World Energy Outlook, an annual publication that outlines long-term forecasts by the International Energy Agency in Paris, calls on producers like Saudi Arabia to expand their investments to meet a projected 40 percent jump in oil demand by 2030. 
To meet these needs, the agency estimates that $3 trillion is needed for oil exploration, development and refining worldwide during the next 25 years. Middle East and North African producers will need to double their investments to $23 billion a year, or more than $614 billion -- twice the average annual amount spent over the last decade in these regions, according to the report.
 But the energy agency, which represents the interests of oil-consuming nations, including the United States, acknowledged that some countries might not be willing to invest in higher output. Instead, they may seek to curb their output growth, leading to higher oil prices.
 ''If these countries do not increase their investments substantially, we will end up with difficulties on the energy markets,'' said Fatih Birol, the energy agency's chief economist. ''We may end up with much higher prices.'' Mr. Birol, speaking from Paris ahead of the report's release, said, ''The issue in the oil business today is not the reserves but the money, the investment decisions, the investment climate.''
 The energy agency acts as a policy adviser and forecaster for industrialized nations, and its reports are widely read by governments worldwide and the energy industry. But the agency's political bias toward oil-consuming nations sometimes leads it to produce assessments that some consider unrealistic. 
 For example, under the agency's model, Saudi Arabia would need to bring its production up to 18 million barrels a day by 2030 to meet the jump in demand. Today, it produces about 10.5 million barrels a day. 
 Saudi Arabia, which does not allow foreign investments in its oil exploration and production sectors, has disputed such high forecasts in the past. Its own public investment plans call for increasing output to 12.5 million barrels a day by 2009. Saudi officials have said they could increase production to 15 million barrels a day -- but no more -- and sustain such levels for 50 years. 
 The issue of access to reserves, which executives highlighted last year as a main concern, has been overshadowed recently by the debate over whether global oil production is peaking. Mr. Birol said the issue was whether investments were made, not whether reserves existed.
 ''Saudi Arabia has the oil reserves and the domestic capital to boost their production,'' Mr. Birol said. ''But they might not want to increase their investments to boost production. They may want to influence the world price environment.''
 But oil-producing nations can be wary of allowing major foreign investments in their national oil sectors. They may fear creating a glut in supplies that would lead to lower prices, or they may doubt bullish projections for demand. 
 For the first time, Mr. Birol said, the agency has produced an alternative forecast that takes into account lower investments from OPEC and Saudi Arabia, the world's top oil producer. The figures are so low, in fact, that they are below the kingdom's longer-term targets.
 In that so-called deferred scenario, Saudi Arabia's output in 2030 is predicted as 14 million barrels a day, with prices at $86 a barrel by then. 
 It is not the first time that the energy agency has highlighted the need for more investments by OPEC members. The theme has become fairly common for the agency, which has repeatedly asked oil producers to open their energy sectors to foreign companies.
 This year, the report focuses on nine countries in the Middle East and North Africa that have most of the world's oil and gas reserves.
 ''There is considerable uncertainty about the pace at which investment in the region's upstream industry will occur,'' the report said. ''The implications for the rest of the world are profound.''

HEADLINE: A High-Profile Trial, a TV Show And a Son-in-Law in Charge

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO

 BODY:
Television viewers in Montgomery, Ala., might have an opportunity to get to know Richard M. Scrushy, the former chief executive of the HealthSouth Corporation, a lot better. 
 Mr. Scrushy's son-in-law, Michael Plaia, acquired a cable television station in the area just weeks before Mr. Scrushy appeared in federal court to plead not guilty to charges of bribing a former governor of Alabama. And Mr. Plaia said he was open to broadcasting ''Viewpoint,'' a religious show that Mr. Scrushy was host of in Birmingham, Ala., while on trial there. 
 Was the Montgomery purchase a coincidence? Yes, according to Mr. Plaia, who is married to Mr. Scrushy's daughter Christa. ''It was a strategic decision, enabling us to extend our economic reach,'' said Mr. Plaia. ''At the end of the day, we're a business.'' 
 Mr. Plaia drew attention back in January when he spent $2 million to acquire control of a local cable television station near Birmingham, where Mr. Scrushy, 52, was on trial on charges of money-laundering, conspiracy and securities fraud. That station, which reaches more than 200,000 homes in the Birmingham area, broadcast a daily update on Mr. Scrushy's legal travails, ''The Scrushy Trial With Nikki Preede,'' with a former local television reporter as host, as well as ''Viewpoint,'' with Mr. Scrushy and his wife, Leslie. In June, a jury acquitted Mr. Scrushy on all 36 federal counts. 
 Now Mr. Scrushy is accused by federal prosecutors of arranging to cover $500,000 in debts that former Gov. Don Siegelman of Alabama incurred in 1999 while he was pushing for a state lottery. Prosecutors say that in exchange for the help, Mr. Siegelman appointed Mr. Scrushy to a board that oversees requests for hospitals to expand their services. (HealthSouth, Mr. Scrushy's former company, is the nation's largest chain of rehabilitation hospitals.)
 Mr. Plaia's television venture now has the capacity to reach 360,000 households around Alabama, or more than one million potential viewers. A day before submitting his plea on the bribery charges, Mr. Scrushy held a news conference on the set of ''Viewpoint,'' which is still being broadcast in Birmingham, proclaiming his innocence. 
 Mr. Scrushy said through a spokesman that he had no plans to ask his son-in-law to take the program to his new trial venue. 
 But Mr. Plaia said: ''I hope Richard would want to expand his coverage. I'm proud that he's my father-in-law.'' SIMON ROMERO
